sources.snippet: There was a two-kilometer-long secret tunnel constructed in the Amer Fort that led to the Jaigarh Fort, and it was located behind the Zanana Palace. The walls of Jaigarh Fort were said to have been built stronger and more fortified than that of Amer Fort. The tunnel was built to allow the Royal Family to escape to the Jaigarh Fort if Amer Fort was attacked.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Jaigarh Fort, located in Jaipur, was built in the 18th century by Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh II to protect the Amber Fort complex. The fort spans 3 km in length and 1 km in breadth and offers stunning views of Maota Lake and Amer Fort. It houses temples, residential complexes, and well-preserved water reservoirs. One of its main attractions is the Jaivana Cannon, known as the world's largest cannon on wheels.

reviews.reviewText:
I recently visited Jaigarh Fort in Jaipur, and it was a wonderful experience. Perched on the Aravalli hills, the fort offers stunning panoramic views of Jaipur and the surrounding landscape. The massive walls, intricate architecture, and historical charm make it a delight for history lovers.

The highlight of the visit was seeing the Jaivana Cannon, the world’s largest wheeled cannon, which is a true masterpiece. The fort is well-preserved, with spacious courtyards, underground passages, and fascinating museums showcasing royal artifacts and weapons.

The peaceful atmosphere and the breathtaking views make it a perfect spot for photography and exploration. Jaigarh Fort is a must-visit for anyone interested in history, architecture, and stunning views.

I visited Jaigarh Fort recently and really enjoyed it. The fort is huge and gives a great view of the surrounding area. One of the main attractions is the world’s biggest cannon on wheels, called "Jaivana Cannon." It’s really amazing to see such a massive cannon from so many years ago. The fort feels strong and simple compared to some other forts, but it has its own charm. If you like history and great views, Jaigarh Fort is definitely worth a visit.

of warfare.

Explore The Museum

The opulent monument houses a museum curled up at the left of Awami Darwaza, which allows you to get insights into the lives of the Royal families and warriors. The museum exhibits pictures of the Royal family, stamps, hand-drawn designs of the palace made by the architects of that time, and many other artifacts.

Ancient Temples

Explore some of the ancient temples at the fort, the Ram Harihar Temple of the 10th century and the Kal Bhairav Temple of the 12th century.

Other Tourist Attractions

Some of the other noteworthy architectures are Diwan-i-Aam, Shubhat Niwas, and the Diya Burj, which is the highest point of the fort.

Jaigarh Fort is a must-visit in Jaipur for its grand architecture, stunning views of the Aravalli hills, and rich history. The fort is well-preserved, and the world’s largest cannon on wheels is truly impressive. Walking along the massive walls feels like stepping back in time. A perfect spot for history lovers and photographers alike!

The Ganesh Pol, a magnificent entry gate of the Amer Fort's Diwan-e-Khas, stands as a testament to both architectural brilliance and cultural symbolism. Built in the 17th century by Maharaja Man Singh I, this gate holds historical and spiritual significance.

The Ganesh Pol is named after the Hindu deity Lord Ganesh, who is revered as the remover of obstacles. The gate's name reflects its role in symbolically cleansing and purifying individuals before entering the Diwan-e-Khas, which served as a private audience hall for the king.

The gate is adorned with intricate frescoes, ornate carvings, and delicate lattice work, showcasing the exceptional craftsmanship of that era. Its architectural features include elephant trunks, lotus petals, and motifs of gods and goddesses, all intricately crafted in red sandstone and marble.

The Ganesh Pol not only served as a functional gateway but also as a visual representation of the ruler's power and grandeur. It's a stunning example of the fusion of Mughal and Rajput architectural styles, reflecting the cultural richness of the time.

As you pass through the Ganesh Pol, you step into a realm where history, artistry, and spirituality converge. The gate provides a glimpse into the opulence and sophistication of the Mughal and Rajput courts, offering a mesmerizing experience that lingers in the hearts of visitors.

#GaneshPol #AmerFort #ArchitecturalSplendor #CulturalHeritage

Sheesh Mahal (Mirror Palace) inside Amber Fort is truly a jewel of Jaipur’s royal heritage. The moment you step into this part of the fort, you’re greeted by a dazzling sight — walls and ceilings covered in thousands of tiny convex mirrors, intricate glass mosaics, and floral patterns inlaid with precious stones. Even a single candle or ray of sunlight transforms the whole hall into a shimmering galaxy of reflections.

Built during the reign of Maharaja Man Singh in the 16th century and further enhanced by later rulers, Sheesh Mahal was used as a royal reception hall and private chamber for the queens. One of its most fascinating features is its ability to illuminate with minimal light — a single flame could create the effect of a starry night sky, allowing the royals to enjoy beauty and warmth without open flames.

The craftsmanship here is beyond words. Every mirror piece is hand-cut, and every floral motif is painted with natural colors, showing the unmatched skill of artisans from centuries ago. It’s not just architecture; it’s poetry in glass and stone.

Photography here is an absolute delight, but nothing compares to seeing it with your own eyes — the way light dances across the walls feels almost magical. The area is well-maintained, though due to preservation efforts, some parts are restricted for visitors, which is understandable given its delicate nature.

If you’re visiting Amber Fort, Sheesh Mahal is the heart of the experience. Take your time here, look closely at the details, and imagine the royal gatherings, music, and laughter that once filled this sparkling hall.

⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

We reached the fort via a scenic drive from Jaipur and walked up the pathway, admiring its grandeur. The mirror work in Sheesh Mahal and the stunning hilltop views were unforgettable. Amber Fort’s rich history and architectural beauty made my visit truly special.

The Sheesh Mahal at Amer Fort, also known as the Palace of Mirrors, is an architectural marvel that showcases the brilliant artistry of the Mughal and Rajput eras. Built in the 17th century by Mirza Raja Jai Singh, this magnificent structure was designed with a specific purpose: to allow the queen to experience a starry night sky without having to sleep in the open.
​Its most striking feature is the intricate mirror work that covers the walls and ceilings.  Thousands of tiny, convex mirrors and colored glass pieces are meticulously arranged in complex floral and geometric patterns. This design creates a breathtaking effect where a single ray of light or the flame of a single candle is reflected countless times, illuminating the entire hall in a dazzling, star-like glow.
​The exquisite craftsmanship is a testament to the skill of the artisans of that time, who painstakingly hand-cut and inlaid each piece. The architectural details, including the use of white marble and the blend of Islamic and Rajasthani motifs, demonstrate a sophisticated fusion of styles. This fusion makes the Sheesh Mahal a unique and captivating part of the Amer Fort complex.
​While entry to the inner chamber is now restricted to preserve the delicate artwork, visitors can still admire its splendor from the outside. The Sheesh Mahal stands as a symbol of royal opulence, artistic excellence, and a king's profound love, making it a truly unforgettable sight.

Amber Fort, Jaipur: A Detailed Review

Overview:
Amber Fort (or Amer Fort), located 11 km from Jaipur, is one of Rajasthan's most iconic landmarks and a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Built in 1592 by Raja Man Singh I and later expanded by successive rulers, the fort combines Mughal and Rajput architecture. Perched on a hill, it offers breathtaking views of Maota Lake and the surrounding landscape.

---

Key Highlights

1. Architectural Grandeur:

Constructed with red sandstone and marble, the fort features a blend of imposing strength and intricate artistry.

Sheesh Mahal (Mirror Palace): The most famous section, adorned with beautiful mirrors and intricate carvings that sparkle under light.

Diwan-i-Aam & Diwan-i-Khas: Public and private audience halls showcasing splendid frescoes and delicate designs.

Ganesh Pol: A gateway with exquisite frescoes, leading to the private quarters of the Maharaja.

2. Historical Significance:

Amber Fort served as the royal residence and a defense structure.

Rich in legends, it reflects the opulence of Rajput rulers and their strategic ingenuity.

3. Light and Sound Show:

An evening attraction that narrates the fort’s history through dramatic storytelling, sound effects, and lighting.

4. Maota Lake:

The picturesque lake at the base of the fort enhances its beauty and offers opportunities for stunning photographs.

5. Cultural Activities:

Elephant rides to the fort's entrance (optional but controversial due to ethical concerns).

Traditional puppet shows and local artisans near the fort.

---

Visitor Experience

Positives:

Historical Immersion: A perfect destination for history and architecture enthusiasts.

Scenic Beauty: Offers panoramic views of Jaipur and the surrounding hills.

Rich Cultural Vibes: Traditional performances and exhibitions add to the charm.

Negatives:

Crowded: Popular among tourists, it can get crowded, especially during weekends or festivals.

Accessibility: Reaching the top can be tiring; alternatives include jeeps or elephant rides.

Entry Fees: Slightly higher ticket costs, with additional charges for guides and certain areas.

---

Tips for Visitors

Best Time to Visit: Visit early morning or late afternoon to avoid the heat and crowds.

Duration: Allocate 2-3 hours to explore the fort thoroughly.

Guide or Audio Guide: Opt for a guide to learn about the fort's history and architecture in depth.

Ethical Concerns: Consider walking or taking a jeep instead of an elephant ride.

Evening Visit: Stay for the light and sound show for a unique experience.

---

Conclusion

Amber Fort is a jewel in Jaipur

Shri Jagat Shiromani Temple in Amer, Jaipur, is a revered Hindu shrine dedicated to Lord Krishna and Vishnu. Built between 1599 and 1608 AD by Queen Kanakwati in memory of her son Jagat Singh, the temple holds historical and spiritual significance. It houses the same idol of Lord Krishna worshiped by Meera Bai, a devoted saint and poet, over 600 years ago. This idol was saved from destruction during the Mughal war with Mewar state and later brought to Amer.

What makes this temple unique is that it is the only one in the world where idols of Lord Krishna and Meera Bai are worshiped together. Meera Bai considered Lord Krishna her spiritual husband, and the temple reflects their special bond. With its rich history and spiritual value, the Jagat Shiromani Temple is a monument of national importance and an essential part of Amer's heritage.

The Jagat Shiromani Temple is a masterpiece of Rajasthani architecture, with intricate carvings and stunning designs that transport you to a world of divine beauty. Its majestic structure, adorned with sculptures of trumpeting elephants and horses, seems to come alive with stories from mythological texts. The temple's strategic location on a small hill adds to its grandeur, making it a breathtaking sight to behold. As you step inside, the serene atmosphere and exquisite craftsmanship will leave you spellbound, making it a must-visit destination for anyone who appreciates art, history, and spirituality.

Drawbacks

The Zanana, or Women's Quarters, within the majestic Amber Fort in Jaipur, is a captivating testament to the architectural marvels of Rajasthan. My exploration of this historically significant space was seamlessly facilitated by Google Maps, which expertly guided me through the intricate pathways of the fort to reach the Zanana with ease.

The journey to the Zanana began at the main entrance of the Amber Fort, where Google Maps provided clear directions, leading me through the fort's captivating architecture and bustling courtyards. Its accuracy in navigating the complex layout of the fort ensured that I reached the Zanana without any confusion.

As I entered the Women's Quarters, Google Maps continued to be a valuable companion, helping me navigate through the various chambers and courtyards that make up this secluded section of the fort. The app's indoor mapping feature proved especially useful, ensuring I didn't miss any of the architectural nuances and historical artifacts within the Zanana.

The Zanana, designed to provide privacy and exclusivity to the women of the royal household, is a labyrinth of stunning courtyards, ornate chambers, and intricate architecture. Google Maps helped me appreciate the layout of this historically rich space, ensuring I followed a path that allowed for a comprehensive exploration.

The app's street view feature allowed me to virtually stroll through the Zanana, offering a close-up view of the delicate jali work, vibrant frescoes, and architectural details that adorned the quarters. This feature enhanced my understanding of the historical and cultural significance of this secluded area.

In conclusion, the Zanana at Amber Fort is a hidden treasure within the larger tapestry of Rajasthan's architectural heritage. Google Maps, acting as a reliable guide, made my journey through this historically rich space both informative and enjoyable. For those intrigued by the secrets of royal life in Rajasthan, the Zanana is a must-visit destination, and with Google Maps, the exploration becomes a seamless and enriching experience.

reviews.reviewText:
Visiting Amber Fort was truly a memorable experience! I highly recommend going early in the morning – the temperature is pleasant, and the crowd is minimal, making it perfect to explore the fort peacefully and click great photos without much disturbance.

A small tip: do not book a jeep to reach the fort entrance. It’s completely unnecessary. The walk uphill is hardly 200-300 meters and very manageable, even in casual footwear.

Hiring a guide is a must if you want to understand the rich history and architectural details of the fort. The official guide charges are ₹400 for a group of 1-4 people and ₹600 for a group of 6-14. It’s definitely worth it for the added insight.

One important caution: avoid buying souvenirs from the shops inside the fort. They are extremely overpriced – you can find the same items outside the fort or in the local markets for 4-5 times cheaper.

Overall, Amber Fort is stunning and offers a great start to your Jaipur trip if you plan wisely!

Amber Fort is one of those places that leaves you awestruck the moment you see it........Huge, majestic, and full of history, it easily takes 2–3 hours to explore........though you’ll hardly notice the time passing. The Sheesh Mahal is simply magical........the tiny mirrors sparkle beautifully, even in the faintest light.
I’d highly recommend taking a local guide........they share fascinating stories, little-known facts, and bring the fort’s past to life in a way that signboards never can. The architecture is stunning........with a perfect blend of Rajput charm and Mughal elegance, and the views of Maota Lake from the top are picture-perfect.
If you can........arrive early to enjoy the elephant ride up to the fort........it’s a unique, royal touch to the experience. For a different vibe........there’s also a light and sound show in the evening that tells the fort’s history beautifully.
Amber Fort isn’t just a sightseeing spot........it’s a walk through Rajasthan’s glorious past........and honestly........it’s one of Jaipur’s must-visits.

Amber Fort is a must-visit when in Jaipur — the architecture, history, and views are truly mesmerizing. It’s highly recommended to hire a government-certified guide (around ₹400), as they give you a real understanding of the fort’s history and also help with the best photo spots. Exploring the fort takes about 1–2 hours including photo sessions.

To avoid the rush, reach by 10–11 am — on weekends, parking queues can stretch up to an hour. If you’re in a cab with a guide, they’ll usually take you through the village shortcut and park at the top, saving you a lot of time. Walking through the fort makes you appreciate how such massive structures were built centuries ago without modern machinery. An unforgettable experience and one of the highlights of Jaipur! If you want to save time, skip the ticket queue by booking through the OBMS app — it’s quick and hassle-free.

You will face hundreds of guide pursuing you to take a guided tour and they will say 150/- for the tour but sometime you will ended up with completing the tour so early you don't even get the vibe of the serene architecture.

Also enjoy going on weekday rather to get a better experience.

Two parking- one on road quite accessible and another just outside fort(quite far away from main road) very thin road but it is one way road. Also if a passenger jeep got stuck there will long traffic line in that road.

Amer Fort is a real gem in Jaipur, a blend of rich history, majestic architecture, and breathtaking views. Each corner of the fort feels like a step back in time, with its grand courtyards, intricate mirror work, beautiful gates, and strong fortified walls. The views from the top are simply amazing, overlooking the city and the surrounding hills. We really enjoyed exploring its stories, taking photos, and soaking in the royal atmosphere. Definitely a must-visit if you’re in Jaipur!

placeMetadata.name: Jaipur

sources.snippet: The magnificent Amber Fort, also called Amer Fort, graces the landscape of Jaipur, a prestigious city in Rajasthan, perched atop a hill with stunning views overlooking Maota Lake, showcasing the grandeur of the Rajput era. Built in the 16th century by Raja Man Singh I, the fort combines Rajput and Mughal architectural styles, offering tourists the delightful experience of exploring it on the back of an elephant, adding a touch of royal splendor to their visit.
sources.shortName: Amer Fort | Jaipur - What to Expect | Timings | Tips

placeMetadata.description: Jaipur is the capital of India’s Rajasthan state. It evokes the royal family that once ruled the region and that, in 1727, founded what is now called the Old City, or “Pink City” for its trademark building color. At the center of its stately street grid (notable in India) stands the opulent, colonnaded City Palace complex. With gardens, courtyards and museums, part of it is still a royal residence.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Jaipur, the vibrant capital of Rajasthan, India, is a city steeped in royal history and architectural splendor. Founded in 1727 by the illustrious royal family, it is affectionately known as the "Pink City" due to its distinctive rosy-hued buildings. At its heart lies the magnificent City Palace complex, which boasts lush gardens and museums while still serving as a royal residence.

reviews.reviewText: The City Palace is one of the highlights of Jaipur. The architecture is breathtaking, with intricate designs, colorful courtyards, and royal halls that showcase the grandeur of Rajasthan. The museum inside offers a glimpse into the royal lifestyle with costumes, weapons, and artifacts. The place is well-maintained and gives you plenty of opportunities for photography. Definitely worth visiting if you’re exploring the Pink City!

The palace of the highness and really good to know that we have a king and prince.
They are really good people promoting state of art and culture to the people.
The palace is really beautiful and clean.
It attracts foreigners and many tourists who come to our country and see our customs and traditions and learn about our country.
Thank you for preserving such a beautiful heritage and traditions.
Very memorable visit and informative also.

I had a wonderful experience at the City Palace—it was clean, well-maintained, and beautifully showcased the grandeur of the royal family. Although there were a few areas under construction, the overall ambiance was impressive.

However, one thing that bothered me was the ticket pricing. The charges are quite high, with separate fees for different sections and museums inside the palace, which can be frustrating. Considering it’s a historical site, it would be great if the ticket prices were kept more affordable so everyone can appreciate and learn from this heritage.

Jaipur City Palace Night Visit – Truly Magical

The City Palace at night is a stunning sight. Beautifully lit and far less crowded, it offers a peaceful, almost royal feel. The guided tour was informative, and the illuminated architecture looked even more majestic under the night sky. A unique and memorable experience—highly recommended!

Historical and beautiful intricate patterned palace that showcases antique collections of Royal family of Jaipur. The descendents of then Maharaja of Jaipur resides in one separate palace inside this. There are different tour packages one can opt for. Also tourist guides are available who show around entire palace in an hour with emphasis on what each collections mean. It takes typically 1 hour to stroll around whole area. There is shop also inside having good collection of pashmina and light weight Maharani saris. Entry fee is discounted for students carrying ID card and children.

It's a marvellous building at the centre of the city. The palace is didvided into multiple parts and it's very vast. You'll get a booklet with the ticket as s guide to explore the palace. It's a must visit place you're exploring Jaipur, don't miss it.

Most of the things are getting renovated so playing Rs300 is not worth.

placeMetadata.name: Hawa Mahal

sources.shortName: Amer Fort | Jaipur - What to Expect | Timings | Tips

placeMetadata.description: Palace built in the form of a high wall to screen royal ladies as they watched street festivities.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Hawa Mahal, often referred to as the "Palace of Winds," is a stunning architectural gem located in Jaipur, Rajasthan. Built in 1799 by Maharaja Sawai Pratap Singh, this five-story palace is renowned for its striking facade adorned with numerous small windows known as jharokhas. These intricately designed openings not only enhance the beauty of the structure but also serve a practical purpose by allowing cool breezes to flow through, making it an early form of natural air conditioning.
placeMetadata.address: Hawa Mahal Rd, Badi Choupad, J.D.A. Market, Pink City, Jaipur, Rajasthan 302002, India

reviews.reviewText:
Hawa Mahal, or the “Palace of Winds,” is one of the most iconic landmarks in Jaipur. Built in 1799, this beautiful five-story palace made of red and pink sandstone is known for its 953 small windows, called jharokhas, designed to let cool air flow through the building.

The front of Hawa Mahal looks like a honeycomb or crown and is especially beautiful in the early morning light. Many people love taking photos from across the street, where several rooftop cafés offer the best views. From there, you can capture the full front of the palace—but please note, most cafés only allow photography if you buy something, like a cup of coffee or a snack. It’s a small price for a great experience and view.

Hawa Mahal was originally built so royal women could watch street life and festivals without being seen. Today, you can go inside and walk up the narrow ramps to enjoy beautiful views of the old city and nearby landmarks like Jantar Mantar.

Inside the palace, there are breezy passages, quiet courtyards, and a small museum. It doesn’t take much time to visit, but it’s full of charm and history.

Please also remember not to write or scratch on the walls. It’s a historic site, and we should help protect its beauty.

Hawa Mahal is a must-see in Jaipur—perfect for photography, culture, and a quick coffee with a royal view.

If something in you remembers old stories, quiet dreams, or the simple joy of standing somewhere that has seen centuries pass—Hawa Mahal is made for you. It’s not just a monument; it’s a breath, a glimpse into royal lives, and a haven of artistry.
I’d recommend going early—beat the heat, catch the gentle light, and let yourself be still for a moment. Let the wind, the pink walls, and the stairs carry you a little away from today and into something tender and timeless.

The experience of being inside the palace was equally enriching. Navigating the winding ramps and staircases, I was able to appreciate the intricate details of the architecture up close. The views of the city from the upper floors are breathtaking, offering a panoramic perspective of Jaipur's vibrant streets and surrounding hills. It's a place that perfectly blends historical significance with stunning beauty. Whether you're a history buff, an architecture enthusiast, or simply looking for a glimpse into India's rich heritage, the Hawa Mahal is an absolute must-visit. It's an unforgettable experience that truly embodies the spirit of Jaipur.

I recently visited Hawa Mahal during the daytime. It’s a beautiful and unique building with amazing architecture. But if you really want to see it at its best, I recommend visiting after evening. When the lights turn on, Hawa Mahal looks even more stunning and magical. The whole place lights up and feels much more lively. Daytime visit is nice, but the evening view is definitely more special.

An absolute gem in the heart of Jaipur! Hawa Mahal is breathtaking both in architecture and historical significance. The intricate latticework and honeycomb design are unlike anything else, and the breeze that flows through its 953 windows truly lives up to its name—the "Palace of Winds."

Climbing up through the narrow passages gives you a unique perspective of royal life, and the view from the top over the bustling streets of Jaipur is spectacular. The on-site museum also offers great insight into the heritage of the palace.

A must-visit when in Jaipur—iconic, photogenic, and steeped in history. Five stars without a doubt!!

A must-visit landmark in Jaipur! Hawa Mahal is an architectural gem with stunning façade and intricate lattice windows that truly live up to its name The Palace of Winds. The view from the top gives a beautiful glimpse of the old city.

However, the inside is not as grand as the exterior, and there's not much information displayed about its history - so it helps if you go with a guide or read up a bit beforehand.

Great for photography, especially during sunrise or sunset. Night view is also beautiful with the lights on.

We Visited Hawa Mahal last Saturday — and it truly lives up to its name, the Palace of Winds! 🌬️🏰
The iconic pink sandstone facade with 953 small windows (jharokhas) is not just stunning to look at but also tells stories of royal life and clever architecture. Climbing to the top gives a beautiful panoramic view of Jaipur’s old city, and the cool breeze flowing through the windows is refreshing even in the heat!

Ticket Charges - 52₹ / Person
Guide Charges - 400₹

A must-visit for history lovers, architecture fans, and anyone who wants to experience the soul of Jaipur. 🌸📸

Hawa Mahal is a stunning five-storey palace in Jaipur, built in 1799 with pink and red sandstone. Its 953 intricate windows allow cool breezes to flow, keeping the palace naturally airy. The honeycomb design is unique and truly breathtaking. A must-visit landmark that beautifully reflects Jaipur’s royal heritage.

placeMetadata.description: Elaborate fort built in 1734 in the hills above Jaipur, offering sweeping views of the city.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nahargarh Fort, built in 1734 above Jaipur, is part of a trio of forts along with Jaigarh and Amer. It was constructed to protect the city and has a rich military history. The fort also houses a wax museum featuring sports stars, freedom fighters, and Bollywood celebrities. Visitors can embark on a cycling expedition to explore the fort in a unique way while enjoying stunning views of Jaipur and Man Sagar Lake.

reviews.reviewText: Nahargarh Fort is one of the best places to visit in Jaipur especially if you enjoy nature and views. The fort is easily reachable by bike with a smooth road and a short ride through scenic hills. The views from the top are just stunning especially during sunset when you can see the whole city of Jaipur. The fort itself has beautiful old architecture and a peaceful vibe. There are a few cafes inside to relax and enjoy snacks. The area is clean and well maintained

A must visit place in Jaipur. You can drive your car up to the top of the hill to reach this fort. Road in good but in the end very narrow. Parking is available near fort. From roof top of this fort, you get best view of entire Jaipur city. Amazing place.

Visited Nahargarh Fort recently and had a great time. The entry ticket is very reasonably priced at just ₹52 per person. The fort is open from 9:00 AM to 9:30 PM, giving you plenty of time to explore at your own pace.

We booked our own bike to get there — cost about ₹50 for parking, which is also fair considering the location and security.

The views from the top are absolutely stunning, especially during sunset. The fort itself is well-maintained and offers a mix of history, architecture, and panoramic city views. Definitely worth a visit if you're in Jaipur!

Would recommend bringing water and wearing comfortable shoes, especially if you plan to walk around a lot. Overall, a memorable and budget-friendly experience. 👍

The sunset view here is awesome. Whole city view vibes here only from Nahargarh fort. See the full pink city from here. It's a very lovely and beautiful view everywhere 👀. In summer going early in the morning or going to evening sunset time is best to see. The afternoon is very hot everywhere. But you have at least 2-3 hours or more to spend here to enjoy everything. Nice journey thnx all.

The experience in the fort is very good but its subject to the weather you're going in. We visited during rainy day and it was quite good (we had umbrellas with us) the view of the city from top of the fort is breathtaking. We miss some local food items near or within the fort. If they were there then it will be an add up to overall experience.

Visited Nahargarh Fort just in time for the sunset, and it was absolutely breathtaking. The sky lit up in beautiful shades of orange, and watching the Jaipur city lights begin to twinkle from above was a magical experience. If you have an evening free in Jaipur, I highly recommend this. The view is 100% worth it!

Visited Nahargarh Fort recently and it’s truly a must-visit! The day view is breathtaking, but the night view with sparkling city lights is simply unforgettable.
The place does get hot during the day, so the best time to visit is from mid-August to February.

A small tip: you’ll find monkeys around in the evening. Avoid carrying water bottles in your hand or teasing them – I had one snatch mine! Bring some extra water for them instead.

Overall, an amazing spot for photography and one of the best city views I’ve ever seen. Highly recommend!

Nahargarh Fort offers one of the most stunning views of Jaipur, especially from the top. The architecture has a true Rajasthani touch, with beautiful designs that reflect heritage and culture. Standing here gives you a special feeling of connection with history and the lives of our ancestors.

This picturesque oasis was once the primary water source for the renowned Amer Fort and played a crucial role in the region's history. The tranquil waters of Maotha Lake offer an ideal setting for relaxation and leisurely activities such as swimming. Visitors can also admire the reflection of the nearby Amber Palace on the lake's surface, creating a captivating sight.
placeMetadata.address: Devisinghpura, Amer, Rajasthan 302028

reviews.reviewText:
Maota Lake, Amer Fort: A Serene Escape

Breathtaking Views
Maota Lake offers stunning views of Amer Fort against a backdrop of lush hills. It’s a peaceful spot to relax and take photos, especially at sunrise or sunset. A perfect complement to your visit to the fort!

Tranquil Atmosphere
The serene ambiance of Maota Lake is a welcome contrast to the bustling fort. The gentle sound of water and the sight of colorful boats make it a lovely place to unwind. Highly recommended for a moment of reflection.

Great for Photos
This lake provides some of the best photo opportunities in Jaipur. The reflections of the fort on the water are simply magical. Make sure to bring your camera!

A Historical Gem
The lake is not just beautiful; it’s steeped in history as well. The connection between Maota Lake and Amer Fort adds depth to your visit. Take some time to learn about its significance.

Perfect for a Stroll
Walking around Maota Lake is a delightful experience. The pathways are well-maintained, and you can enjoy the views while soaking in the history of the area. A must-visit when exploring Amer Fort!

Maota Lake is located in the south of the city of Amber, about 11 kilometers from the center of Jaipur, at the base of Amber Fort. The lake contains an island in the center, named Kesar Kyari Bagh. The island has a saffron garden, whose plants are said to have been planted by a Maharaja in the 15th century. The Dil-Aaram Bagh is situated on the northern end of the lake. There is no fee to visit the lake, but there is a fee to traverse upward (or ride an elephant) to enter the Amber Fort above.

The lake collects rain water flowing down from the nearby hills and was the main source of water for the Amber Fort and common people. In Jaipur, after 7 or 10 days of Ganesh chaturthi,[6] the statue is taken in a procession for immersion in the Maota Lake.

placeMetadata.name: Tunnel of Jaigarh Cannon foundry

sources.shortName: The Only Travel Guide You Will Ever Need

placeMetadata.address: JAIGARH FORT, Devisinghpura, Amer, Rajasthan 302028, India

reviews.reviewText: I have gotten lots fun there, and learn history of jaigarh fort.

Tunnels are to be found quite commonly in the palaces and forts of the medieval period. They were used to conceal movement or to allow of escape when during a seige the defenders were being pushed hard.
Lying on the western side of the palace, the Amber Palace tunnel connects it to the Jaigarh fort, It is subterraneous till a point near the Rang Mahal. Thereafter, it runs, roofless, on the surface, up to Jaigarh.
The tunnel is accessible from the Man Singh Palace, Zenāni Deorhi (Ladies' Apartments) and Diwán-i-Khās. Torches provided light in it.

Cannon foundry at the Jaigarh Fort was the brain child of Maharaja Man Singh Ji-I. Its plans were based on his extensive knowledge of  cannons gleaned on his Kabul campaign in the 16th century as commander of Akbar’s army. It covers an area of  about 9000 square feet. The furnace and the drilling complex are its two major parts.The furnace its self is of the dimensions of 24 X 12 X 10 feet. It is an open hearth furnace where very high temperatures of about 1000 to 1200 degree Celsius can be attained.There are two charging windows and three chimneys.The hearth of the furnace is oval and made of fire bricks and clay.There are two opening in its ceiling which open into the chimneys above.The hearth has a small 2X2 feet window which opens into the pit outside so that the molten metal can fall into the mould and take its shape. A 72 feet long tunnel in the lower part of the furnace worked as a wind tunnel.

The Drilling Complex is an octagonal room with the ceiling at the height of 31 feet where the barrels of cannons moulded in the foundry were bored.  Four pairs of oxen were used to turn the levers of the machine which bored the barrel of a cannon in the making.

Jaigarh Cannon foundry has a 72 ft long tunnel.
This tunnel sucks air into the fire chamber attached to the furnace that melts the metal  & the molten metal is used to make solid barrels.
Great experience in the tunnel. On this walkable distance you can experience how the kings soldiers move and protect the forts.
Hidden tunnel, worth of information
Beautiful
Cool tunnel

Believed to date back to the 10th century, the temple holds significant historical and religious importance in the region.  If you are seeking spiritual solace or an appreciation of ancient architecture, Ambikeshwar Mahadev Temple provides a profound glimpse into the religious and cultural tapestry of Rajasthan.

The Ambikeshwar Mahadev Temple in Jaipur is a peaceful retreat dedicated to Lord Shiva. Known for its unique underground Shiva Lingam, the temple exudes an ancient charm and offers a serene, spiritual atmosphere. Its lush surroundings and historical significance make it an ideal spot for both devotion and meditation.

Cons:

Jaipur is the capital of India’s Rajasthan state. It evokes the royal family that once ruled the region and that, in 1727, founded what is now called the Old City, or “Pink City” for its trademark building color. At the center of its stately street grid (notable in India) stands the opulent, colonnaded City Palace complex. With gardens, courtyards and museums, part of it is still a royal residence.

data.title: The 24 best photo spots in Amer

placeMetadata.name: Hawa Mahal

sources.snippet: While many people just view Hawa Mahal from the outside, I loved the chance to head inside and look out from the same windows I’d been looking up at minutes before. While this building is famous for its iconic pink facade, its history is what drew me in.The wives of the maharajas (and in fact many women of the time) weren’t allowed to be seen in public without their husbands and instead, were hidden away in elaborate buildings such as Hawa Mahal. Here, they lived lives of luxury but weren’t allowed to mix with the rest of the world.
sources.shortName: 12 Instagrammable Places in Jaipur To Take Photos – Where Goes Rose?

sources.snippet: One of Jaipur’s most iconic and distinctive landmarks, the Hawa Mahal was constructed in 1799 by Maharaja Sawai Pratap Singh as a way to allow ladies of the royal household to watch life on the streets below without being seen themselves. The five-storey tall honeycomb hive facade consists of 953 latticework windows for the ladies’ viewing pleasure. This famous perspective of the palace is actually on the rear side facing the main road, meaning that getting a shot through the traffic can be tough.
sources.shortName: The Most Instagrammable Spots in Jaipur, Rajasthan

sources.snippet: A post shared by Tourist Places By Yash (@touristplacesbyyash). The pink-hued outer walls of the Hawa Mahal, with its beautiful windows and intricately painted structures, makes for one of the most popular and picturesque spots in Jaipur. You can stand in front of the Mahal to get the perfect Instagrammable capture and round up your trip to Jaipur, or head to one of the rooftop cafes across the road, which offer one of the best views of the Mahal, and the perfect backdrop to flaunt your outfits!
sources.shortName: Visiting Jaipur? These Places Have The Most Instagrammable Backdrops

sources.snippet: Hawa Mahal, also known as, the Palace of Winds was specifically built so that the royal ladies of Jaipur could see street festivities without revealing themselves. The famous honeycomb structure consisting of 953 windows is actually the rear view of the building and its best part too. Instead of doing a tour of the palace itself, it is best to visit a café across the road and admire Hawa Mahal away from the hustle and bustle of the busy street that it stands on.
sources.shortName: A Local's Guide To Best Instagrammable Spots In Jaipur

sources.snippet: Here are some popular places in this ancient capital city that are perfect for taking pictures: Suggested Tour: Jaipur Sightseeing Tour, Jaipur Taxi Service, Jaipur Tour ## Hawa Mahal Hawa Mahal is a palace in Jaipur, India. It was built by Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh II and it is one of the most popular tourist attractions in Jaipur. Hawa Mahal is a five-storey building with an open courtyard and it has been called 'the jewel of Rajasthan'.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Photo Spots in Jaipur

sources.snippet: Hawa Mahal is known as the Palace of the Winds because of its 953 windows on its façade, so the air could enter and refresh the interior. The window design had also another intention: that the royal ladies could observe the daily life and the festivals outside, since they couldn’t show their face in public. Plus, this iconic façade is actually the back of the palace, which is located in a very noisy and busy street.
sources.shortName: Instagram spots in Jaipur – Diana Miaus

sources.snippet: Also known as the Wind Palace, the Hawa Mahal is one of the most beautiful sights you can see in Jaipur. Painted a vibrant pink color, and well maintained, it’s a striking sight to see the combination of color and funky architecture that this palace is composed of. To get the best view and photos, I’d suggest viewing from across the street at the Wind Cafe for a great vantage point.
sources.shortName: 10 Best Instagram Spots in Jaipur

sources.snippet: The massive edifice of Hawa Mahal stands at the intersection of the main road in Jaipur, Badi Chaupad and was built by Maharaja Sawai Pratap Singh in the year 1799. Hawa Mahal derives its name from its unique structure, which is a mesh of small windows that allowed cool wind to enter the palace and hence kept the palace comfortable during the hot summer months.
sources.shortName: 52 Best Places to visit in Jaipur | Top Tourist Attractions

sources.snippet: Hawa Mahal (Wind Palace) — The Hawa Mahal, also known as the Palace of the Winds, is an iconic piece of architecture in Jaipur. The name comes from the 953 small windows built in to keep wind from blowing in the palace. The palace is a difficult spot to photograph as it’s in the middle of a busy street lined with markets and restaurants.
sources.shortName: Best Photo Spots in Jaipur

sources.snippet: Hawa Mahal means the palace of winds and it’s the most iconic spot in the city & the one of most Instagrammable places in Jaipur!. Constructed in 1799 for Maharaja Sawai Pratap Singh for the women of his house. He was an ardent worshipper of the Hindu deity Lord Krishna and the design is meant to resemble Krishna’s crown.
sources.shortName: 11+ Stunning Most Instagrammable Places In Jaipur (2025)!

sources.snippet: Hawa Mahal, known as the "Palace of Winds", is an iconic architectural marvel in Jaipur, India. The palace was built in 1799 by the Maharaja Sawai Pratap Singh. It is famous for its distinctive honeycomb facade that is adorned with 953 intricately carved windows, showcasing the best of Rajput craftsmanship.
sources.shortName: 30 Places to Visit in Jaipur, Tourist Places & Top Attractions

sources.snippet: Also called the Palace of the Winds, the majestic grand facade contains 953 windows to let air in. If you look closer at the windows, you’ll see that they’re pretty small, with some made of tiny holes. The reasoning for this was so the royal ladies could see out but the public couldn’t see in.
sources.shortName: Jaipur Most Instagrammable and Photogenic Spots

sources.snippet: Our first sight was one Garth really wanted to photograph – the Hawa Mahal. Built in 1799 from pink and red sandstone this five storey palace looks just like the Ministry of Magic from the Harry Potter movies. It has 365 lattice windows, one for everyday of the year in a honeycomb design.
sources.shortName: 10 Stunning Photography Locations in Jaipur, India

sources.snippet: Also known as the Palace of Winds, this marvelous pink-red structure has often been made a part of national and international cinemas. So having your wedding photo shoot at this location is a MUST!. It is situated in the heart of Jaipur city and can be reached very easily.
sources.shortName: 14 Best Pre Wedding Shoot Locations Jaipur

sources.snippet: The Hawa Mahal is the best spot to see why Jaipur's nickname is the pink city!. This spot looks like a fairy tale as the colors are so beautiful. I'd recommend wearing something pink here because then your outfit will match the beautiful pink city!
sources.shortName: 9 Best Instagram Photo Spots in Jaipur

sources.snippet: One of the most instagrammable spots in Jaipur, the Hawa Mahal or the Palace of Winds derives its name from the many windows on its façade  through which fresh air passes.
sources.shortName: Jaipur the most Instagrammed city of Rajasthan

placeMetadata.description: Palace built in the form of a high wall to screen royal ladies as they watched street festivities.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Hawa Mahal, often referred to as the "Palace of Winds," is a stunning architectural gem located in Jaipur, Rajasthan. Built in 1799 by Maharaja Sawai Pratap Singh, this five-story palace is renowned for its striking facade adorned with numerous small windows known as jharokhas. These intricately designed openings not only enhance the beauty of the structure but also serve a practical purpose by allowing cool breezes to flow through, making it an early form of natural air conditioning.
placeMetadata.address: Hawa Mahal Rd, Badi Choupad, J.D.A. Market, Pink City, Jaipur, Rajasthan 302002, India

reviews.reviewText:
Hawa Mahal, or the “Palace of Winds,” is one of the most iconic landmarks in Jaipur. Built in 1799, this beautiful five-story palace made of red and pink sandstone is known for its 953 small windows, called jharokhas, designed to let cool air flow through the building.

The front of Hawa Mahal looks like a honeycomb or crown and is especially beautiful in the early morning light. Many people love taking photos from across the street, where several rooftop cafés offer the best views. From there, you can capture the full front of the palace—but please note, most cafés only allow photography if you buy something, like a cup of coffee or a snack. It’s a small price for a great experience and view.

Hawa Mahal was originally built so royal women could watch street life and festivals without being seen. Today, you can go inside and walk up the narrow ramps to enjoy beautiful views of the old city and nearby landmarks like Jantar Mantar.

Inside the palace, there are breezy passages, quiet courtyards, and a small museum. It doesn’t take much time to visit, but it’s full of charm and history.

Please also remember not to write or scratch on the walls. It’s a historic site, and we should help protect its beauty.

Hawa Mahal is a must-see in Jaipur—perfect for photography, culture, and a quick coffee with a royal view.

If something in you remembers old stories, quiet dreams, or the simple joy of standing somewhere that has seen centuries pass—Hawa Mahal is made for you. It’s not just a monument; it’s a breath, a glimpse into royal lives, and a haven of artistry.
I’d recommend going early—beat the heat, catch the gentle light, and let yourself be still for a moment. Let the wind, the pink walls, and the stairs carry you a little away from today and into something tender and timeless.

The experience of being inside the palace was equally enriching. Navigating the winding ramps and staircases, I was able to appreciate the intricate details of the architecture up close. The views of the city from the upper floors are breathtaking, offering a panoramic perspective of Jaipur's vibrant streets and surrounding hills. It's a place that perfectly blends historical significance with stunning beauty. Whether you're a history buff, an architecture enthusiast, or simply looking for a glimpse into India's rich heritage, the Hawa Mahal is an absolute must-visit. It's an unforgettable experience that truly embodies the spirit of Jaipur.

I recently visited Hawa Mahal during the daytime. It’s a beautiful and unique building with amazing architecture. But if you really want to see it at its best, I recommend visiting after evening. When the lights turn on, Hawa Mahal looks even more stunning and magical. The whole place lights up and feels much more lively. Daytime visit is nice, but the evening view is definitely more special.

An absolute gem in the heart of Jaipur! Hawa Mahal is breathtaking both in architecture and historical significance. The intricate latticework and honeycomb design are unlike anything else, and the breeze that flows through its 953 windows truly lives up to its name—the "Palace of Winds."

Climbing up through the narrow passages gives you a unique perspective of royal life, and the view from the top over the bustling streets of Jaipur is spectacular. The on-site museum also offers great insight into the heritage of the palace.

A must-visit when in Jaipur—iconic, photogenic, and steeped in history. Five stars without a doubt!!

A must-visit landmark in Jaipur! Hawa Mahal is an architectural gem with stunning façade and intricate lattice windows that truly live up to its name The Palace of Winds. The view from the top gives a beautiful glimpse of the old city.

However, the inside is not as grand as the exterior, and there's not much information displayed about its history - so it helps if you go with a guide or read up a bit beforehand.

Great for photography, especially during sunrise or sunset. Night view is also beautiful with the lights on.

We Visited Hawa Mahal last Saturday — and it truly lives up to its name, the Palace of Winds! 🌬️🏰
The iconic pink sandstone facade with 953 small windows (jharokhas) is not just stunning to look at but also tells stories of royal life and clever architecture. Climbing to the top gives a beautiful panoramic view of Jaipur’s old city, and the cool breeze flowing through the windows is refreshing even in the heat!

Ticket Charges - 52₹ / Person
Guide Charges - 400₹

A must-visit for history lovers, architecture fans, and anyone who wants to experience the soul of Jaipur. 🌸📸

Hawa Mahal is a stunning five-storey palace in Jaipur, built in 1799 with pink and red sandstone. Its 953 intricate windows allow cool breezes to flow, keeping the palace naturally airy. The honeycomb design is unique and truly breathtaking. A must-visit landmark that beautifully reflects Jaipur’s royal heritage.

placeMetadata.name: The City Palace

sources.snippet: Still owned by the Jaipur royal family, this architectural gem is a lovely mixture of intricate doorways, manicured gardens, and bursts of color that will dazzle your senses. Diwan-I-Khas is the brick red building lined with arches and was used as a private audience hall for royal guests. Continuing onwards, make sure you continue to the inner courtyard (Pritam Niwas Chowk) where there are four doorways that are elaborately decorated with the four season in mind.
sources.shortName: Jaipur Most Instagrammable and Photogenic Spots

sources.snippet: Jawahar Circle Garden is another location that has become Instafamous as of late. It seems that every one that is anyone in the blogosphere just has to capture an image of themselves nonchalantly frolicking through its brightly coloured archway and concourse in a billowing dress and floppy-rimmed hat. Believe it or not, this isn’t an opulent palace, tomb, or one of Rajasthan’s many magnificent forts but the inside of Jawahar Circle Garden’s entrance gate.
sources.shortName: The Most Instagrammable Spots in Jaipur, Rajasthan

sources.snippet: Located in the centre of Jaipur, The City Palace is the present day home of the Royal Family of Jaipur and is an absolute must see on my list. The four seasonal gates and the pink courtyard of the City Palace are known to Instagrammers across the globe. But, in my opinion, the best part about the entire place is actually the blue room called Sukh Niwas that is hidden in a private part of the palace which could be visited for an extra 2500 Rupees.
sources.shortName: A Local's Guide To Best Instagrammable Spots In Jaipur

sources.snippet: After the Hawa Mahal, the Jaipur City Palace doors are the most iconic photo spot in Jaipur. Painted with intricate designs and bold colors, and sparkling gold paint, be sure to prioritize seeing these beautiful doors during your visit to Jaipur. This is one of the top tourist attractions in Jaipur, so be sure to visit first thing in the morning when they open, and head straight to the doors in the back courtyard.
sources.shortName: 10 Best Instagram Spots in Jaipur

sources.snippet: ## City Palace Jaipur City Palace Jaipur, also known as Amber Fort, is a royal residence in Jaipur. It is one of the largest palace complexes in the world and has been declared as a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1987. The palace complex was built by Maharajas of Jaipur between 1528-1843 AD with an area of over 30000 square meters (32 hectares).
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Photo Spots in Jaipur

sources.snippet: Located in the old part of Jaipur is the City Palace, built in 1729 by Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh. Over the years later Maharajas added various wings and pavilions. It costs 700 INR (£7.10) to visit the palace’s few buildings including a museum displaying artefacts from Royal costumes, weapons to miniature paintings.
sources.shortName: 10 Stunning Photography Locations in Jaipur, India

sources.snippet: The magnificent City Palace in Jaipur is one of the most famous tourist attractions located in the old part of the city. Built by Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh during the years 1729 to 1732, the vast complex of the palace occupied one-seventh of the walled city. In fact, it was once the seat of the Maharaja of Jaipur.
sources.shortName: 52 Best Places to visit in Jaipur | Top Tourist Attractions

sources.snippet: When the court of royalty moved from Amer Fort to Jaipur, a new city place was built by Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh II in 1727. The architecture of this palace is jaw-dropping and colourful inside and out!. The most iconic feature of this palace is the intricate doorways in the inner courtyard or Pritam Niwas Chowk.
sources.shortName: 11+ Stunning Most Instagrammable Places In Jaipur (2025)!

sources.snippet: Embark on a majestic visual journey through the City Palace in Jaipur with a captivating photoshoot. Begin by capturing the grandeur of the palace's entrance, showcasing its architectural opulence. Explore inner courtyards adorned with ornate arches and columns, playing with light and shadow for dramatic effects.
sources.shortName: 10 Best Locations For Photo Shoot in Jaipur 2024

sources.snippet: In the heart of Jaipur stands the City Palace, a marvel of architecture. Built by Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh II in the 18th century, it is a grand complex of courtyards, buildings, and gardens. This palace showcases the royal heritage of Jaipur, blending Rajputana and Mughal architecture.
sources.shortName: 30 Places to Visit in Jaipur, Tourist Places & Top Attractions

sources.snippet: If you are passionate about architecture, art, history and doors… you’re going to love it. One of the most surprising rooms of the City Palace are the 4 gates that symbolize summer, spring, fall and winter and are dedicated to different gods and goddesses for different reasons.
sources.shortName: Instagram spots in Jaipur – Diana Miaus

sources.snippet: City Palace — Another popular spot in Jaipur, you’ve probably seen photos of the blue room. This room, along with others, are only available if you pay an additional $50. I skipped it for this time, but you still have access to the main hall, which is also stunning.
sources.shortName: Best Photo Spots in Jaipur

sources.snippet: You could probably scrap everything else in Jaipur, just visit the City Palaceand still come back with some impressive Instagram shots!. My first question on arrival was ‘so where’s the gate?
sources.shortName: 12 Instagrammable Places in Jaipur To Take Photos – Where Goes Rose?

sources.snippet: Popular for its colourful corridors, large decorated doors, courtyards and more, a visit to Jaipur is incomplete without posing for a couple of photos at the Peacock Gate.
sources.shortName: Jaipur the most Instagrammed city of Rajasthan

sources.snippet: The City Palace is also one of the best Instagram photo spots in Jaipur. This place is also very pink. If you love the color pink, I'm sure you will love Jaipur.
sources.shortName: 9 Best Instagram Photo Spots in Jaipur

placeMetadata.description: Opulent 18th-century palace of Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh II, now a museum & royal residence.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The City Palace in Jaipur is an opulent 18th-century palace that once served as the residence of Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh II and is now a museum. It's a popular historical attraction known for its beautiful collection of paintings, textile gallery, armory, Durbar hall, BaggiKhana, and SarvatoBhadraor (Diwan E-Khas) with exquisite architectural beauty.
placeMetadata.address: Gangori Bazaar, J.D.A. Market, Pink City, Jaipur, Rajasthan 302002, India

reviews.reviewText: The City Palace is one of the highlights of Jaipur. The architecture is breathtaking, with intricate designs, colorful courtyards, and royal halls that showcase the grandeur of Rajasthan. The museum inside offers a glimpse into the royal lifestyle with costumes, weapons, and artifacts. The place is well-maintained and gives you plenty of opportunities for photography. Definitely worth visiting if you’re exploring the Pink City!

The palace of the highness and really good to know that we have a king and prince.
They are really good people promoting state of art and culture to the people.
The palace is really beautiful and clean.
It attracts foreigners and many tourists who come to our country and see our customs and traditions and learn about our country.
Thank you for preserving such a beautiful heritage and traditions.
Very memorable visit and informative also.

I had a wonderful experience at the City Palace—it was clean, well-maintained, and beautifully showcased the grandeur of the royal family. Although there were a few areas under construction, the overall ambiance was impressive.

However, one thing that bothered me was the ticket pricing. The charges are quite high, with separate fees for different sections and museums inside the palace, which can be frustrating. Considering it’s a historical site, it would be great if the ticket prices were kept more affordable so everyone can appreciate and learn from this heritage.

Loved This Palace It's Very Beautiful... Our  Guide Was Very Good N If You Ask Him Any Questions He Told It In Detail All... The Palace Was Very Pleasant N Wonderful Atmosphere... They Have Kept Very Clean & Well Maintained... They Allow Only Photo You Can't Take Video... Must Visit Once...

Jaipur City Palace Night Visit – Truly Magical

The City Palace at night is a stunning sight. Beautifully lit and far less crowded, it offers a peaceful, almost royal feel. The guided tour was informative, and the illuminated architecture looked even more majestic under the night sky. A unique and memorable experience—highly recommended!

One of the top attraction in Jaipur.
Entry is priced @ 350₹ per person
Tour guide is priced @ 400₹ for 2 persons.
Prefer tour guide to know the history of the palace.
Armoury section is closed for renovation.
We spent around 2 hours for complete tour.

Historical and beautiful intricate patterned palace that showcases antique collections of Royal family of Jaipur. The descendents of then Maharaja of Jaipur resides in one separate palace inside this. There are different tour packages one can opt for. Also tourist guides are available who show around entire palace in an hour with emphasis on what each collections mean. It takes typically 1 hour to stroll around whole area. There is shop also inside having good collection of pashmina and light weight Maharani saris. Entry fee is discounted for students carrying ID card and children.

The City Palace in Jaipur is a true gem! Its stunning architecture, royal charm, and rich history make it a must-visit. The blend of Mughal and Rajasthani styles is breathtaking, and every corner feels like stepping back into a royal era. An unforgettable experience!

For Indians it is 300 Rs per person

placeMetadata.name: Panna Meena ka Kund

sources.snippet: Amber Fort was declared as UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1984 ## Panna Meena Ka Kund Panna Meena Ka Kund is a stepwell located in Amer, a small town in the outskirts of Jaipur, Rajasthan. It is a beautiful and unique architectural structure that was built in the 16th century by the Panna Meena community. The stepwell is known for its intricate and symmetrical design, with staircases that intersect at a 90-degree angle, creating a mesmerizing geometric pattern.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Photo Spots in Jaipur

sources.snippet: Panna Meena ka Kund — located just about a 10 minute walk from Amer Fort (or you can just pay your jeep driver to make a stop here on the way to the fort), you have probably seen this stairwell a few times on Instagram. You are not actually allowed to walk down the steps — you will only be allowed on the top step. Despite all the photos you may have seen, those people most likely bribed the guards to be allowed to go further down.
sources.shortName: Best Photo Spots in Jaipur

sources.snippet: Panna Meena ka Kund in Jaipur is a historic stepwell known for providing water to locals and serving as a community gathering spot. It dates back to the 16th century and though no longer a water source, it remains a popular destination for locals and tourists to socialize. Youngsters jump into the water during summer, while elders and couples enjoy its serene ambiance.
sources.shortName: 30 Places to Visit in Jaipur, Tourist Places & Top Attractions

sources.snippet: Panna Meena Ka Kund has become something of an internet darling as of late. It doesn’t feel like a single day goes by without me seeing a dozen photos of it cropping up in my Instagram feed. Built in the 16th century as a way of collecting the monsoon rains, the stepwell was a centre point for the community, used as a water source, bathing pool and for washing clothes.
sources.shortName: The Most Instagrammable Spots in Jaipur, Rajasthan

sources.snippet: The Panna Meena ka Kund is another Instagram special - geometric staircases in this community stepwell are a feat of historical engineering. The Jal Mahal offers stunning views of the Water Palace and the seasonal sighting of migratory birds. Jantar Mantar, featuring the world's largest sundial, makes for unexpected photographs of giant astronomical instruments.
sources.shortName: Jaipur: Instagram Tour of The Best Photography Spots

sources.snippet: Nearby Amber Fort there is one insta-famous baoli: yellow, symmetrical and highly photogenic. Despite being located so close to Amber Fort, Panna Meen Ka Kund doesn’t receive that many tourists, unless instagrammers or tourists with a private guide. Taking pictures on the stairs is apparently forbidden and if you do so you will be charged with 100 rupees.
sources.shortName: Instagram spots in Jaipur – Diana Miaus

sources.snippet: India is covered with many staggeringly beautiful stepwells, with the one in Jaipur being one of the most accessible and well maintained. Looking like a real life, geometric MC Escher piece of art - the staircases crisscross in a mesmerizing pattern. In the past it was used as a water source, bathing spot, and a place for the community to gather.
sources.shortName: Jaipur Most Instagrammable and Photogenic Spots

sources.snippet: This stepwell in Jaipur is the closest place to Pacman I have ever seen. Situated just about 5 minutes from Amber Fort, Panna Meena Ka Kund is an architectural masterpiece that has slowly gained its fame on Instagram. Truth being told, people are actually not allowed to go on these symmetrical stairs anymore.
sources.shortName: A Local's Guide To Best Instagrammable Spots In Jaipur

sources.snippet: Panna Meena Ka Kund is a stepwell near Amer Fort, which was used in the earlier days to store and use water and for performing religious ceremonies. The place has steps leading down its walls, and the symmetrical structure makes for some stunning captures for Instagram.
sources.shortName: Visiting Jaipur? These Places Have The Most Instagrammable Backdrops

sources.snippet: This stepwell is the smaller version of Chand Baori (in Abhaneri). Such kind of ancient structures is ideal for stunning wedding photoshoots. This baori or kund is open for all and there are no charges (entry tickets or otherwise) for conducting pre-wedding shoots.
sources.shortName: 14 Best Pre Wedding Shoot Locations Jaipur

sources.snippet: Panna Meena Kund’s step-well has lately shot into fame because many travelers have featured this place on their Instagram feed and blogs. While previously, one could walk down the water reservoir through the steps, now it’s prohibited and guards ensure compliance.
sources.shortName: Pre-Wedding Photo Shoots in Jaipur

sources.snippet: 11 km from city center 27 out of 75 Places To Visit in Jaipur. Panna Meena ka Kund in Jaipur is one of the many famous stepwells that still stand in the western part of India. The historical stepwell is known for its symmetrical staircase on all four sides.
sources.shortName: 52 Best Places to visit in Jaipur | Top Tourist Attractions

sources.snippet: I wasn’t sure whether to include this one as it’s come under fire recently. But, as I believe it’s photo-worthy enough without anyone in it, I’ll include it. The stepwells of Rajasthan are famous and can be found all over the state.
sources.shortName: 11+ Stunning Most Instagrammable Places In Jaipur (2025)!

sources.snippet: This place is very beautiful, and taking photos of all the stairs is so much fun!. You can be very creative here and take many different pictures. Furthermore, it's also an interesting sight to see when you're in Jaipur.
sources.shortName: 9 Best Instagram Photo Spots in Jaipur

placeMetadata.description: Historic stepwell & rainwater catchment known for its picturesque symmetrical stairways.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Panna Meena ka Kund is a historic stepwell and rainwater catchment located near Amber Fort in Jaipur. Dating back to the 16th century, this architectural wonder features picturesque symmetrical stairways on three sides and a multi-story balcony on the fourth. It is a popular spot for photography, especially during monsoon rains when it transforms into a peaceful oasis.
placeMetadata.address: XVR2+FGV, Amer, Rajasthan 302028, India

reviews.reviewText:
Nice photo shoot here. Came here in the early morning before visited in Amber fort.

We hire a car from hotel. The driver pick-up the guide then sent us here for the first place: the guide helped us to take a photo at the best shooting frame:

We like it here!

Great place to click pictures.
It is kept very clean and well maintained.
There are shops which sell local handicrafts on a way more lesser price than amer fort.
Good place to shop too.
Ticket is minimal.
Interesting place to visit.

"Panna Meena Kund is a hidden gem in Jaipur! I visited on 15th August and despite the huge crowd, the stepwell's beauty shone through. The intricate architecture, stunning water features, and rich history make it a must-visit attraction. The crowd didn't deter me from appreciating the kund's unique charm and tranquility. ♥️

A small but nice place to learn how water gets stored in old times. Good place for clicking pics. No entry charge but less parking space. You won't able to get parking in weekends. Kund have lots of turtles and fishes.

A Hidden Gem in Jaipur!

Panna Meena ka Kund is a beautifully preserved stepwell and one of the most unique places I visited in Jaipur. The symmetrical steps and geometric design are truly fascinating — it's a great spot for photography and soaking in some quiet history. It's not as crowded as other tourist sites, which makes the experience even more peaceful.

Some interesting stories about its historical use for water conservation and as a community gathering spot, especially for women in earlier times. You can't go down the steps anymore (as per current rules), but even from the top, the view is stunning.

In front of the kund, there’s an ancient temple that adds to the charm and spiritual feel of the place. It’s a small but beautifully carved temple, and visiting it makes the whole experience even more special. The peaceful atmosphere around both the stepwell and the temple gives a glimpse into the cultural and architectural richness of Rajasthan.

If you're in Jaipur, definitely make time for this — it's just a short drive from the Amer Fort!

It’s beautiful, many ppl spam there even on weekdays, there’s also a temple nearby. Honestly, Very hyped, not that aesthetic, urgently in need of maintenance, especially before the rainy season.
And mind you, you can’t go in, it’s a fineable offense.
But that was the whole point!!! To get pictures!
You can take them after paying 5k, said the guard:)
🥲🥲🥲

If you’re in Jaipur for a long weekend and are looking to kill time on your way back from Amber Palace, stop at the Panna Meena ka Kund to experience an authentic Rajasthani step well.

While the maintenance isn’t the best and the water not the cleanest, it’s an architectural beauty of Rajasthan’s popular step wells.

While many people come here for photo shoots, during our afternoon visit, the police/security weren’t allowing individuals to use the steps to reach down.

PS: If you’re lucky, you might witness a turtle taking a dip in the waters | There is no entry fee.

Though it’s not one of the architecturally intricate step wells, it still has an old world charm. Glad that the administration decided to stop people from going down the stairs. It preserves both the well and ensures safety of visitors. Visiting in the early morning hours can enhance the experience.

placeMetadata.name: Jal Mahal

sources.snippet: It says a lot about the sheer quantity of beautiful buildings on display in Jaipur that the Jal Mahal, or ‘Water Palace’, isn’t overrun with visitors peering across Man Sagar Lake in the hope of glimpsing it. In any other city, it would be the main tourist draw. At the moment, the palace is undergoing extensive renovations meaning that it cannot be accessed but it is worth stopping off on the road between Jaipur and Amer to take a look and capture a few photographs.
sources.shortName: The Most Instagrammable Spots in Jaipur, Rajasthan

sources.snippet: The Jal Mahal offers stunning views of the Water Palace and the seasonal sighting of migratory birds. Jantar Mantar, featuring the world's largest sundial, makes for unexpected photographs of giant astronomical instruments. Do not forget Jaipur's signature landmark, the Hawa Mahal or Palace of Winds, the most photographed building in the city.
sources.shortName: Jaipur: Instagram Tour of The Best Photography Spots

sources.snippet: Jal Mahal, the Water Palace, is a stunning architectural marvel situated in the midst of Man Sagar Lake in Jaipur. Built in the 18th century, its unique feature is the single exposed story, showcasing exquisite Rajput and Mughal styles. Nestled against the backdrop of the Aravalli hills, the palace offers a tranquil and picturesque setting.
sources.shortName: 30 Places to Visit in Jaipur, Tourist Places & Top Attractions

sources.snippet: Sitting prettily right in the centre of the Man Sagar Lake on the outskirts of Jaipur, lies the splendid and tranquil Jal Mahal. A masterful creation, it is bordered by the Nahargarh Hills. This low rise symmetrical Palace was once a shooting lodge for the Maharajas and now fascinates many visitors from all over the world.
sources.shortName: 52 Best Places to visit in Jaipur | Top Tourist Attractions

sources.snippet: Jal Mahal is built on a lake and it literally means Palace on the Water. Years ago it was accessible by boat but nowadays it’s highly polluted – you will notice that bad smell as soon as you get there. The best way to visit is on your way between Amber Fort and Jaipur, as it is located on the side of the main road.
sources.shortName: Instagram spots in Jaipur – Diana Miaus

sources.snippet: On your way back to Jaipur from Amber Fort ask your tuk tuk driver to stop for photos of the stunning Jal Mahal palace located in the middle of Lake Man Sagar with a backdrop of the Rahargarh Hills. Jal Mahal means “Water Palace”. Jal Mahal – photo taken on the way back to Jaipur after visiting Amber Fort
sources.shortName: 10 Stunning Photography Locations in Jaipur, India

sources.snippet: Jal Mahal is my favourite spot to watch the sun rise from in Jaipur. If there is anything that beats a magical sunrise than it is a magical sunrise behind a lake palace in India. However, if you cannot make it here for sunrise, then I would suggest you visit it on your way back to Jaipur from Amer town.
sources.shortName: A Local's Guide To Best Instagrammable Spots In Jaipur

sources.snippet: Jal” means water and “Mahal” means mansion or palace, so this literally translates to water palace. It’s a gorgeous building that sits in the middle of Man Sagar Lake. It was constructed by Maharaja Jai Singh II in the Rajput style in 1799.
sources.shortName: 11+ Stunning Most Instagrammable Places In Jaipur (2025)!

sources.snippet: This gorgeous palace is built in the middle of the Man Sagar Lake. And The most preferred locations for pre-wedding video or photo shoot in Jaipur. Many couples capture alluring sunrise pictures on the banks of this heritage property.
sources.shortName: 14 Best Pre Wedding Shoot Locations Jaipur

sources.snippet: One of the most popular reasons for this being a top-rated place among couples is that one can get a stunning backdrop of Jal Mahal or the Water Palace. It is less crowded during the early morning hours.
sources.shortName: Pre-Wedding Photo Shoots in Jaipur

sources.snippet: Jal Mahal is located in the heart of Jaipur City and a well known tourist spot. Its very easily accessible by all means of transport. You have public transport as well to reach this place.
sources.shortName: Jal Mahal - Best Photo Spots

sources.snippet: While unfortunately, you can’t take a boat out to get closer to the Jal Mahal palace, you can still get a great view and photos from shore. Just make sure you have a good zoom lens 🙂
sources.shortName: 10 Best Instagram Spots in Jaipur
Jaipur the most Instagrammed city of Rajasthan

placeMetadata.description: In the middle of Man Sagar Lake sits this grand palace made of red sandstone, most of it submerged.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Jal Mahal, also known as the Water Palace, is a grand red sandstone palace situated in the middle of Man Sagar Lake in Jaipur. Built in the 18th century by Sawai Madho Singh, it was originally intended as a summer resort for the royal family and guests. The palace's unique location makes it one of Jaipur's most famous landmarks.
