reviews.reviewText: It's A great place to view click pictures with your friends and family. Spending a good time here. Buy something for home decoration eat street food. Camel 🐪 ride most important here. Historic place has great vibes here.

Jal Mahal, Jaipur is a beautiful architectural gem located in the middle of the lake, but currently, entry into the palace is not allowed. Visitors can only enjoy its scenic beauty from the shore. The best time to visit is early morning—perfect for a peaceful walk, fresh air, and a pleasant view. The calm lake, cool breeze, and feeding the fishes add to the experience. A great spot to sit, relax, and enjoy the surroundings. Ideal for individuals, couples, and families. A must-visit photo stop while exploring Jaipur.

As entry isn't allowed, so no tickets. Just spend the time by walking and just seating, chilling and enjoying the beautiful view. A palace in Lake and perk is it's green mount background. Away from high rise building, only you and nature.
Management should work over cleanliness here.

Great spot for photography and a beautiful view. Maintenance could be better, and boating should start again to enhance the experience. Nearby you’ll find food stalls, cultural products, and options to click pictures in traditional Rajasthani attire

Jal Mahal is a great place to visit, and the best part is that there’s no entry fee. However, one thing to keep in mind — it’s not the best spot to visit during the rainy season. The area around the water tends to collect a lot of waste, and the outer paths can become quite slippery.

Despite that, I had a good overall experience. Worth a visit

Jal Mahal is a pretty spot to visit in Jaipur. The view of the palace in the middle of the lake is amazing, especially in the evening. It does get a bit crowded since both tourists and locals enjoy hanging out here, and honestly, the place could be kept a little cleaner. But overall, it’s a nice stop to enjoy the scenery and click some great pictures.

Jal Mahal – the palace that floats like a dream! 🌊🏰
Set right in the middle of Man Sagar Lake, this beauty is a peaceful escape from the city buzz. The view during sunrise or sunset? Pure magic! 🌅✨

Though entry inside isn’t allowed, the view from the promenade is royal enough 💖📸. Surrounded by hills, birds, and calm waters – it’s a picture-perfect spot for a stroll or chill vibes 🦢🌿.

It's very nice place you got here selfie point and click photos of Rajasthani culture and arts
Jal Mahal (meaning "Water Palace") is a palace in the middle of the Man Sagar Lake in Jaipur city, the capital of the state of Rajasthan, India.

placeMetadata.name: Nahargarh Fort

sources.snippet: Being the highest point in the city, Nahargarh Fort is really the best place to watch the sun set over Jaipur. Regardless of how many pictures are posted in which Instagrammers can be seen walking on the fort walls, I want to be honest and let you know that the drop on the other side of the walls is actually scary in real life, at least for me it is. Instead, you can just find a good seat at Padao café and watch the sun set over Jaipur.
sources.shortName: A Local's Guide To Best Instagrammable Spots In Jaipur

sources.snippet: Built in 1734, Nahargarh Fort stands high above the northern limits of Jaipur, casting an imposing shadow over the city. The fort was originally named Sudarshangarh, but it became known as Nahargarh, which means ‘abode of tigers’. Local legend says that the fort was named for Nahar Singh, a dead prince whose spirit was thought to be disrupting construction only sated once a temple was built within the grounds.
sources.shortName: The Most Instagrammable Spots in Jaipur, Rajasthan

sources.snippet: This wasn’t my favourite excursion in Jaipur because I felt the 200 rupee entrance fee was expensive since there wasn’t much to see inside the fort, plus they wanted an extra 200 for the sunset viewpoint. Despite this, you can’t deny that Nahargarh Fort is one of the most Instagrammable places in Jaipur. You get a panoramic view of the whole city, all the way out to the mountains on the horizon.
sources.shortName: 12 Instagrammable Places in Jaipur To Take Photos – Where Goes Rose?

sources.snippet: Usually combined with visits to the Amber Fort and Panna Meena Ka Kund Stepwell, the views from Nahargarh Fort are one of the big reasons to visit. You can literally wander all the hallways and ramparts all day long if you wanted to. But to maximize your visit, at least check out the meandering rampart fort walls around sunset which will afford you some grand views of Jaipur.
sources.shortName: Jaipur Most Instagrammable and Photogenic Spots

sources.snippet: Whether you’re looking for pretty gates, city views or the old-time structures, Nahargarh Fort has them all – and then some more. The fort sits atop a hill and offers some of the best views of the Pink City below. What’s more, its various rooms, mahals, terrace structures and more are the perfect way to round up tour Jaipur tour with the most Instagram-worthy shots.
sources.shortName: Visiting Jaipur? These Places Have The Most Instagrammable Backdrops

sources.snippet: Nahargarh Fort, situated on the outskirts of Jaipur, is known for breathtaking views of the city and for its extended wall that connects it to Jaigarh Fort. Embellished with delicate carvings and stonework, the Nahargarh Fort is an impregnable structure and together with its two neighbouring forts - Amer and Jaigarh once stood as the strong defence of Jaipur city.
sources.shortName: 52 Best Places to visit in Jaipur | Top Tourist Attractions

sources.snippet: Nahargarh Fort sits on the Aravalli Hills, offering stunning views of the entire city of Jaipur. Built back in 1734 by Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh II, it showcases a blend of Indian and European architecture. Once a royal retreat, the fort is famous for its Madhavendra Bhawan which is adorned with intricate frescoes.
sources.shortName: 30 Places to Visit in Jaipur, Tourist Places & Top Attractions

sources.snippet: Perched atop the Aravalli Hills, Nahargarh Fort in Jaipur unfolds as a picturesque haven for photography enthusiasts. Capture the fort's majestic exterior against the changing hues of the sky, framing the Pink City below. Explore historic corridors and intricate details that resonate with Rajasthan's valor.
sources.shortName: 10 Best Locations For Photo Shoot in Jaipur 2024

sources.snippet: On the top of Aravalli hill, Nahargarh Fort offers the best view over the Pink City. I’m sure you have seen many photographs from this location on Instagram, with people jumping or walking on the walls. The height is crazy and the wind is too so please, don’t risk your life for a picture.
sources.shortName: Instagram spots in Jaipur – Diana Miaus

sources.snippet: While I wasn’t able to make it here during my trip, I would recommend taking in the beautiful vista from Nahargarh Fort, especially at sunset. This is where you can find the classic spot of an arched fortress wall that many people perch on for great photos overlooking Jaipur!
sources.shortName: 10 Best Instagram Spots in Jaipur

sources.snippet: Together with two other forts, it used to form a strong defense ring for the city. It was built in 1734. People believed Nahar Singh Bhomia's spirit haunted the place and obstructed the construction of the fort, This explains the name of the fort.
sources.shortName: 9 Best Instagram Photo Spots in Jaipur

sources.snippet: Nahargarh fort is an ideal spot to witness a magical sunset. If you are here during the day, take a stroll through the courtyards of Nahargarh Fort and get amazed by its simplicity. The fort also houses a wax museum and a majestic restaurant.
sources.shortName: Jaipur the most Instagrammed city of Rajasthan

sources.snippet: There is nothing better than a view from the top and Jaipur has many hills to choose from. Nahargarh Fort provides the best views in the city by far. Plus, there are lots of attractions, restaurants, and places to grab a drink.
sources.shortName: 11+ Stunning Most Instagrammable Places In Jaipur (2025)!

placeMetadata.description: Elaborate fort built in 1734 in the hills above Jaipur, offering sweeping views of the city.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nahargarh Fort, built in 1734 above Jaipur, is part of a trio of forts along with Jaigarh and Amer. It was constructed to protect the city and has a rich military history. The fort also houses a wax museum featuring sports stars, freedom fighters, and Bollywood celebrities. Visitors can embark on a cycling expedition to explore the fort in a unique way while enjoying stunning views of Jaipur and Man Sagar Lake.
placeMetadata.address: Krishna Nagar, Brahampuri, Jaipur, Rajasthan 302001, India

reviews.reviewText: Nahargarh Fort is one of the best places to visit in Jaipur especially if you enjoy nature and views. The fort is easily reachable by bike with a smooth road and a short ride through scenic hills. The views from the top are just stunning especially during sunset when you can see the whole city of Jaipur. The fort itself has beautiful old architecture and a peaceful vibe. There are a few cafes inside to relax and enjoy snacks. The area is clean and well maintained

A must visit place in Jaipur. You can drive your car up to the top of the hill to reach this fort. Road in good but in the end very narrow. Parking is available near fort. From roof top of this fort, you get best view of entire Jaipur city. Amazing place.

Visited Nahargarh Fort recently and had a great time. The entry ticket is very reasonably priced at just ₹52 per person. The fort is open from 9:00 AM to 9:30 PM, giving you plenty of time to explore at your own pace.

We booked our own bike to get there — cost about ₹50 for parking, which is also fair considering the location and security.

The views from the top are absolutely stunning, especially during sunset. The fort itself is well-maintained and offers a mix of history, architecture, and panoramic city views. Definitely worth a visit if you're in Jaipur!

Would recommend bringing water and wearing comfortable shoes, especially if you plan to walk around a lot. Overall, a memorable and budget-friendly experience. 👍

The sunset view here is awesome. Whole city view vibes here only from Nahargarh fort. See the full pink city from here. It's a very lovely and beautiful view everywhere 👀. In summer going early in the morning or going to evening sunset time is best to see. The afternoon is very hot everywhere. But you have at least 2-3 hours or more to spend here to enjoy everything. Nice journey thnx all.

The experience in the fort is very good but its subject to the weather you're going in. We visited during rainy day and it was quite good (we had umbrellas with us) the view of the city from top of the fort is breathtaking. We miss some local food items near or within the fort. If they were there then it will be an add up to overall experience.

Visited Nahargarh Fort just in time for the sunset, and it was absolutely breathtaking. The sky lit up in beautiful shades of orange, and watching the Jaipur city lights begin to twinkle from above was a magical experience. If you have an evening free in Jaipur, I highly recommend this. The view is 100% worth it!

Visited Nahargarh Fort recently and it’s truly a must-visit! The day view is breathtaking, but the night view with sparkling city lights is simply unforgettable.
The place does get hot during the day, so the best time to visit is from mid-August to February.

A small tip: you’ll find monkeys around in the evening. Avoid carrying water bottles in your hand or teasing them – I had one snatch mine! Bring some extra water for them instead.

Overall, an amazing spot for photography and one of the best city views I’ve ever seen. Highly recommend!

Nahargarh Fort offers one of the most stunning views of Jaipur, especially from the top. The architecture has a true Rajasthani touch, with beautiful designs that reflect heritage and culture. Standing here gives you a special feeling of connection with history and the lives of our ancestors.

A beautiful blend of history, culture and breathtaking scenery definitely a must-visit

placeMetadata.name: Albert Hall Museum

sources.snippet: Albert Hall Museum was the first place we visited in Jaipur on the Palace on Wheels itinerary: what a way to start the trip!. The light in the morning was perfect, the pigeons flew into our pictures every couple of minutes and it was the perfect appetizer of what our time in Jaipur would look like and what we expected in Rajasthan: pure beauty!. Although my photo is taken in front of the museum, I think it’s way easier to capture the hundreds of pigeons from the outside.
sources.shortName: Instagram spots in Jaipur – Diana Miaus

sources.snippet: Situated in the Ram Niwas Garden of Jaipur, the Albert Hall Museum is the oldest museum in Rajasthan. Built in 1876, it was initially envisioned to be a concert hall and resembles the architecture of the Victoria and Albert Hall Museum in London, hence, the name. It is a standing example of the Indo-Saracenic architecture and is also known as Government Central Museum.
sources.shortName: 52 Best Places to visit in Jaipur | Top Tourist Attractions

sources.snippet: I am sure that most of us have wondered about people using Photoshop to add birds into their pictures, haven’t we?. Well, you do not have to spend hours editing when you are visiting Albert Hall Museum in Jaipur. Located in Ram Niwas garden, this museum is home to many pigeons that enjoy making a special appearance in your photos in exchange for some grains.
sources.shortName: A Local's Guide To Best Instagrammable Spots In Jaipur

sources.snippet: The Albert Hall Museum in Jaipur, Rajasthan, is a splendid architectural gem, showcasing a diverse collection of artifacts, including paintings, sculptures, and decorative arts. Built-in 1887, it combines Indo-Saracenic and European architectural styles. The museum provides a rich cultural experience, narrating the history and artistry of Rajasthan.
sources.shortName: 30 Places to Visit in Jaipur, Tourist Places & Top Attractions

sources.snippet: ## Albert Hall Museum The architecture of the Albert Hall Museum is a fusion of Indian and European styles. The building features beautiful arches, domes, and towers, with intricate carvings and designs. Overall, the Albert Hall Museum is a beautiful and fascinating destination that offers a glimpse into the rich history and culture of Rajasthan.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Photo Spots in Jaipur

sources.snippet: The Albert Hall Museum, also known as the Government Central Museum, is the state museum of Rajasthan. The museum has many interesting things to see, such as paintings and jewelry. I would highly recommend going inside this museum when you're in Jaipur!
sources.shortName: 9 Best Instagram Photo Spots in Jaipur

sources.snippet: Throughout the entire day, this spot is thronged by people clicking themselves in front of the museum amid a flock of pigeons flying around. The real magic of Albert Hall Museum sparks after sunset during the amazing light show spectacle.
sources.shortName: Jaipur the most Instagrammed city of Rajasthan

sources.snippet: This is showing some of the British influence in Jaipur now. The Albert Hall Museum was built in 1876 for the visit of the Prince of Wales. By 1989, there had been over three million visitors to the museum!
sources.shortName: 11+ Stunning Most Instagrammable Places In Jaipur (2025)!

placeMetadata.description: Elegant museum built in 1887 showcasing Indian art, arms, jewels, furniture, artefacts & more.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled within the lush surroundings of Ram Niwas Bagh, the Albert Hall Museum stands as a testament to Jaipur's rich heritage and artistic legacy. Established in 1887, this elegant museum is not only the oldest in the city but also an architectural marvel designed by Sir Samuel Swinton Jacob. The Indo-Saracenic style building, crafted from sandstone and marble, beautifully blends Indian and Victorian influences.
placeMetadata.address: Ram Niwas Garden, Ashok Nagar, Jaipur, Rajasthan 302004, India

reviews.reviewText: Visited the Albert Hall Museum during the day and was truly impressed! The architecture is stunning — a grand, beautifully detailed building that stands out in the heart of Jaipur. Inside, the museum is full of ancient treasures: intricate stone carvings, traditional paintings, royal weapons, textiles, coins, and many fascinating items once used by kings. It’s like stepping back in time. Everything is well-organized and informative. Even though I visited in the daytime, the museum was still full of charm and elegance. Highly recommend spending 1–2 hours here if you’re in Jaipur!

The Albert Hall Museum is a gem of Jaipur: rich in history, art, and architectural beauty. It’s deserving of a visit—especially during cooler seasons or evening hours—though its surroundings and peak crowd times warrant some planning. Here’s to a visit that leaves you inspired!

Albert Hall Museum is truly amazing! I really enjoyed my visit here — it’s one of the best places in Jaipur. The museum is well-maintained, beautifully designed, and full of history. Every section has something unique to offer, from ancient artifacts to cultural displays. A perfect place for history lovers and anyone who wants to explore Jaipur’s rich heritage. Highly recommended!

We wanted to see the museum decorated in light.  It was good.  Good collection but the descriptions are not easily readable.  No info available as why and whose collection ? Few exhibits were not clearly visible because of not enough light.  May be visit in the morning would help. Scope for better maintenance available.

The Albert Hall Museum is a testament to the city's rich cultural heritage.

The museum is housed in a grand 19th-century building which itself is magnificant. Its a mix of Rajput, Mughal, and European architectural styles.

The museum has a collection of artifacts, ranging from ancient pottery and sculptures to textiles and weaponry. Highlights include the Persian carpets, miniature paintings, and an impressive display of traditional Rajasthani costumes or war attire. The Egyptian mummy, a unique centerpiece, adds an element of intrigue, drawing curious visitors of all ages.

The surrounding Ram Niwas Garden adds a serene touch to the visit, perfect for a leisurely stroll post-exploration.

Overall, the Albert Hall Museum is a must-visit for anyone seeking to delve into Jaipur or Rajasthans past. Be mindful about the peak hours though. Also, don’t miss the evening view when the building is beautifully lit!

Museums are brand ambassadors of history, culture and reflection of colloquial flavor and fervor;!!!
The Albert museum stands tall for Jaipur.
It is situated in the heart of the city.its a double storey establishment. It encapsulates the history culture and fragrance of Rajsthan primarily as well as a bit of International touch i.e.Pherao and Mummy artefacts presence makes it like that one only.

The museum showcases arms armors,artefacts,photographs, inscriptions,carvings on walls and rooftops thereby creating an aura of that period
Staff is ok with the Government approach and is well maintained.
Visitors may keep the venue in their Local Itinerary.

Albert Hall Museum is a must-visit in Jaipur! Its grand architecture, ancient artifacts, and beautifully lit exterior at night create a magical blend of history and elegance.
A truly mesmerizing experience! The museum's rare collection, including ancient coins, paintings, and royal costumes, offers deep insight into Rajasthan's heritage. The architecture itself is a visual delight.

Absolutely stunning place! 🏛️ The architecture of Albert Hall Museum is a visual treat, and the collection inside is rich with history and culture. The Egyptian mummy totally blew my mind! 🌍✨
A must-visit when in Jaipur — and don’t miss it lit up at night! 💡

placeMetadata.name: Amber Fort View

sources.snippet: The Amber Fort is not only Jaipur’s most popular tourist attraction, it is also one of the most magnificent buildings in all of Rajasthan. Built with pink and yellow sandstone then embellished with white marble floors and walls, it is infinitely photogenic, especially as the sun fades on an evening, giving the whole fortress an orange and pink hue. The best photographs can be taken from the winding road up to the main entrance and from Jaleb Chowk (Main Courtyard) where you can pose in front of the imposing silver doors on the staircase leading to the main palace.
sources.shortName: The Most Instagrammable Spots in Jaipur, Rajasthan

sources.snippet: The most popular destination for both locals and tourists alike, the Amber Fort is a must see for it’s wide range of architecture, history, and epic views overlooking the city. The best time to visit is right at open, as this place tends to get overrun by many visitors within an hour of opening. But if you can’t make it earlier in the day, that’s totally fine too.
sources.shortName: Jaipur Most Instagrammable and Photogenic Spots

sources.snippet: It’s famous for the elephant ride that takes you there like a Maharajah – luckily, they are about to shut down this activity!. The elephants should not be ridden or forced to walk on the pavement, and many of the elephants in Amber Fort have turnt blind. Remember not to ride the elephants there: just walk or take the jeep, which is way more cool!
sources.shortName: Instagram spots in Jaipur – Diana Miaus

sources.snippet: Probably the most famous landmark in the entire state of Rajasthan, Amber Fort is a palace located in Amer town near Jaipur. This UNESCO World Heritage Site is full of Insta-worthy spots, out of which Ganesh Pol is my all-time favourite. Like most of the touristic places, it is best to reach Amber fort before everyone else.
sources.shortName: A Local's Guide To Best Instagrammable Spots In Jaipur

sources.snippet: ## Amber Fort Amber Fort is a fort located in the city of Jaipur, Rajasthan, India. It was built by the Kachawa Rajputs in the 16th century. It is known for its intricately carved balconies and windows as well as its collection of royal portraits from various periods throughout its history.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Photo Spots in Jaipur

sources.snippet: The biggest landmark of Jaipur is the stunning Amber Fort also called Amer Fort. It’s located in Amer, 7 miles outside Jaipur’s city centre and takes about 30 minutes by tuk tuk to get there. This imposing fort is perched on Amer Hill and is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
sources.shortName: 10 Stunning Photography Locations in Jaipur, India

sources.snippet: I’ve now been twice and I think its my favourite place in the city. The level of detail is crazy and it’s so easy to imagine the royals living there back in the day. The next few places on this list are specific locations you should find at the fort:
sources.shortName: 12 Instagrammable Places in Jaipur To Take Photos – Where Goes Rose?

While the climb to reach this vantage point may be challenging for beginners due to numerous stairs, the breathtaking views from the top make it a memorable experience.

Amer fort is one of the must go places in Jaipur.It's a huge fort. Carry govt Id card for taking ticket. Guide charges 400rs,better to take one as the give us a tour of the place and also take photos of us. Takes approx 2-3 hrs for site seeing. Have to take entry tickets. Take ☔ for scorching heat.

Nice place, Amer is named for its 16th-century fort, a dramatic hilltop stronghold overlooking Jaipur. Often called the Amber Palace, the fort features a hall with intricate mirror mosaics and a Ganesh icon carved from coral. Nearby landmarks include the geometric Panna Meena ka Kund stepwell and Jagat Shiromani, a Hindu temple with a striking statue of goddess Kali.

A must visit if you are in Jaipur!  A fort with a lot of history. Divided into 6 sections, each with its own gate and courtyard. The courtyards are stunning and the grounds are very clean. Cool tunnels to go up and lookout, and tunnels that lead to other forts (which are prohibited). We took the elephant ride up to the top, which was not the most comfortable ride but I feel like one has to do it. What’s really annoying, and unenjoyable is the constant hawkers. They start when you arrive, while you get on the elephant, and the ENTIRE trip up to the top-not taking NO for an answer!  Once at the top, we tipped our mahout and apparently that was not good enough for him-even tho a big sign said “no tipping”.  Stay away and say no to the photographers, they hounded us from the exit all the way to our car and even in our car!! We even had one show up the the restaurant when we walked out-simply RIDICULOUS!  All in all, the fort is beautiful and spacious and clean, it was the extraneous bits that were extremely annoying!

A stunning fort and a pride of Indian history. I would recommend spending at least half a day here if you want to experience the magnificence of this place. Don't do what the others do and run through it like a box to tick off.

Must use the digital tour guide to enjoy it thoroughly.

The Amber fort is pronounce as Amer fort ( Amir fort) so don't confuse while telling the name to your cab or rikshaw driver,  i advice u to book a hotel in tbe city like  i booked hotel pearl square its in the center of the Jaipur .
The amer fort was very huge to explore it has many view points ,firstly when u going to enter in bottom u will see a kulfi wla bhai ( jinhone ek M.N.C company ko resign diya tha) than u go up to the way to amer fort it's so long path to go there in btw u see many things like amrud vendor etc and when u enter in the fort u will feel the real old culture vibe there i will advice u to must visit there if go in jaipur and don't forget to from there to bapu bazar and Sanjay bazar.

A World UNESCO heritage site.. A Jeep Safari from the parking through the narrow roads will take you till the top !! Beautifully built, taking the help of thr local guide will give you the entire story behind the beautifully constructed  fort of Amber. At the top of the fort one can get thr breathtaking views of the lakes and the entire city. The design has been crafted very artistically.
Superb historical fort with amazing architecture. A famous tourist spot with an animal ride facility. Also connects with other local forts by mountain route.

This place is amazing. It’s gigantic and so well preserved. We had a driver so didn’t need to contend with the walk or the jeeps moving you from parking lot to base. The elephant ride is a part of the charm for sure and they are beautifully decorated. The hawkers are plentiful and super aggressive but if you don’t make eye contact they do leave you alone. We saw a few others engage in angry conversations so unless you have intent to buy, I’d suggest not looking or speaking to them. There are 120 working elephants here and it seemed like most of the visitors used them to climb to the fort. I think you can walk up but I’m not sure. Even on the way up the hawkers are shouting at you and part way there are a ton of photographers trying to get you to pose so they can harass you at the top to buy. The elephant drivers start reminding you to tip as soon as you enter the courtyard and just a few rupees will suffice. The complex is huge and we would recommend a guide to understand what you are seeing. The section of mirrored walls is spectacular and there are many spots throughout the complex where amazing pictures can be taken. Our guide also suggested we peek into the keyholes of a few sections that were closed off and we did see some amazing things in these areas not currently open.  Lots to see here and I’m sure the 1.5 hours we spent just scratched the surface. Student charges is just 10 INR.

of warfare.

Explore The Museum

The opulent monument houses a museum curled up at the left of Awami Darwaza, which allows you to get insights into the lives of the Royal families and warriors. The museum exhibits pictures of the Royal family, stamps, hand-drawn designs of the palace made by the architects of that time, and many other artifacts.

Ancient Temples

Explore some of the ancient temples at the fort, the Ram Harihar Temple of the 10th century and the Kal Bhairav Temple of the 12th century.

Other Tourist Attractions

Some of the other noteworthy architectures are Diwan-i-Aam, Shubhat Niwas, and the Diya Burj, which is the highest point of the fort.

I visited Jaigarh Fort recently and really enjoyed it. The fort is huge and gives a great view of the surrounding area. One of the main attractions is the world’s biggest cannon on wheels, called "Jaivana Cannon." It’s really amazing to see such a massive cannon from so many years ago. The fort feels strong and simple compared to some other forts, but it has its own charm. If you like history and great views, Jaigarh Fort is definitely worth a visit.

Jaigarh Fort is a must-visit in Jaipur for its grand architecture, stunning views of the Aravalli hills, and rich history. placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled at the base of Nahargarh Fort in Jaipur, Gaitor Ki Chhatriyan stands as a stunning testament to Rajasthan's rich heritage. This royal crematory is renowned for its intricately carved stone monuments that reflect the grandeur of Rajput architecture blended with traditional Mughal influences. The cenotaphs here honor the legacy of Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh and other former kings, showcasing exquisite craftsmanship through detailed carvings depicting mythological scenes and floral motifs.

reviews.reviewText:
Gaitor Ki Chhatriyan is a hidden treasure of Jaipur. If you’re someone who enjoys history, architecture, or quiet spots with a royal past, this place is a must-visit. It’s an ideal stop for those wanting to go beyond the usual tourist checklist and explore the soul of Jaipur.

Tips for Visiting:
•	Entry fees are minimal and worth every rupee.
•	Visit early morning or late afternoon for the best lighting and fewer people.
•	Don’t forget your camera—the architecture is incredibly photogenic.
•	Pair your visit with a trip to nearby Nahargarh Fort for a full historical experience.

placeMetadata.description: Jaipur is the capital of India’s Rajasthan state. It evokes the royal family that once ruled the region and that, in 1727, founded what is now called the Old City, or “Pink City” for its trademark building color. At the center of its stately street grid (notable in India) stands the opulent, colonnaded City Palace complex. With gardens, courtyards and museums, part of it is still a royal residence.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Jaipur, the vibrant capital of Rajasthan, India, is a city steeped in royal history and architectural splendor. Founded in 1727 by the illustrious royal family, it is affectionately known as the "Pink City" due to its distinctive rosy-hued buildings. At its heart lies the magnificent City Palace complex, which boasts lush gardens and museums while still serving as a royal residence.

Raj Mandir Cinema in Jaipur is a must-visit iconic theater, known for its majestic architecture and vibrant ambiance. Boasting Asia's biggest screen, it offers an unmatched cinematic experience with grand visuals and immersive sound. A perfect blend of heritage and modernity, it’s more than just a movie hall—it’s a cultural landmark.

Raj Mandir Cinema is more than just a movie theatre — it's a heritage landmark and a symbol of Jaipur’s regal charm. Known as one of the most beautiful cinemas in India, its grand Art Deco architecture, luxurious interiors, and royal ambiance make movie-watching a truly memorable experience.

The auditorium is spacious, with comfortable seating and an old-world charm that adds to the overall atmosphere. The lighting, ceiling design, and curtain-raising before the movie begins give a nostalgic, theatrical feel that you won’t find in modern multiplexes.

sound and screen quality are quite good. Located in the heart of the city, it’s easy to reach and often included in city tours.

Raj Mandir Cinema is a movie theatre in Jaipur, Rajasthan. It is the meringue-shaped auditorium opened in 1976, and over the years has seen many movie premieres of Hindi films, and has become a popular symbol of Jaipur. The theatre often referred to as 'Cinema Ka Mandir' is equipped with the latest technology in sound and projection with Dolby Atmos, the first in the state of Rajasthan. An important landmark and tourist destination, the cinema hall has been accorded the status of largest single screen theatre in Asia. The movie theater offers a unique cinematic experience with a large screen and immersive sound system. The interiors are grand and royal, with stunning architecture, colorful lights, and a vintage charm. Feels more like a heritage destination than a regular cinema. Clean toilets, comfortable seats, food and beverages, amazing interiors, beautiful hallways and mesmerizing lighting will make your visit worth to this place.

It was a great experience. I am used to modern cinema in my city, so it was a different experience which I enjoyed.

During my recent visit to Jaipur, I had the privilege of exploring the elegant Maharaniyon Ki Chhatriyan, a magnificent structure that pays tribute to the royal queens of Rajasthan. Located near the stunning Nahargarh Fort, this architectural marvel showcases the regal heritage and artistic finesse of the region. In this realistic review, I will share my personal experiences and insights gained from visiting Maharaniyon Ki Chhatriyan, an enchanting place that preserves the legacy of the royal women of Rajasthan.

Architectural Splendor:
Maharaniyon Ki Chhatriyan exhibits an exquisite display of Rajput architectural brilliance. The intricate carvings, delicate detailing, and elegant domes are a testament to the craftsmanship of the artisans of that era. Each chhatri (cenotaph) is uniquely designed, showcasing different architectural styles and motifs. The vibrant colors and the symmetrical patterns add to the overall grandeur of the monument.

Historical Significance:
This beautiful structure holds immense historical significance as it is dedicated to the royal queens (maharanis) of Rajasthan. It symbolizes their strength, elegance, and contributions to the rich cultural heritage of the state. Visiting Maharaniyon Ki Chhatriyan provided me with a deeper understanding of the royal lineage and the important roles that these powerful women played in shaping the history of Rajasthan.

Serene Ambiance:
The tranquil ambiance of Maharaniyon Ki Chhatriyan is truly captivating. Nestled amidst lush green gardens, the site offers a peaceful retreat away from the bustling city. The well-maintained pathways, shaded seating areas, and the soothing sound of birdsong create a serene atmosphere, making it an ideal place for contemplation and relaxation.

Cultural Insights:
Exploring the chhatris at Maharaniyon Ki Chhatriyan allowed me to gain cultural insights into the rituals and traditions associated with the royal families of Rajasthan. The cenotaphs are adorned with intricate artwork and carvings, reflecting the religious and cultural beliefs of the time. The memorial plaques and inscriptions provide glimpses into the lives and achievements of the queens, further deepening the cultural connection.

Picturesque Views:
The location of Maharaniyon Ki Chhatriyan offers picturesque views of the surrounding landscape. The elevated position provides sweeping vistas of Jaipur's skyline, with the majestic Nahargarh Fort as a backdrop. The golden hues of the setting sun cast a magical glow over the chhatris, creating a captivating scene that is a photographer's delight.

Conclusion:
A visit to Maharaniyon Ki Chhatriyan is a journey into the regal past of Rajasthan and a tribute to the powerful queens who shaped its history. The architectural splendor, historical significance, serene ambiance, cultural insights, and picturesque views make it a must-visit destination for history enthusiasts, architecture lovers, and those seeking tranquility amidst nature. Maharaniyon Ki Chhatriyan preserves the legacy of the royal queens of Rajasthan and offers a glimpse into their opulent lifestyles and significant contributions. It is a place where history comes alive and where the stories of the past continue to inspire and captivate visitors.

After a long walk around the City Palace, we stopped by this café for a much-needed break—and it turned out to be the perfect spot. We had heard about the great view of the Hawa Mahal, and it absolutely lived up to the hype.

To reach the café, you climb a number of stairs lined with small shops on either side, spread across different levels. Just before the final staircase, there's someone at the entrance charging a small fee, which is redeemable as a voucher for food and drinks—so it felt totally fair.

The café is spread over two levels: the first floor is indoors, offering a cool retreat from the sun, while the rooftop terrace on the second floor is where the magic happens. With parasols for shade and an unbeatable view of the Hawa Mahal right across the street, it’s a great spot to relax and soak in the city’s energy from above.

We liked it so much, we ended up going twice. Between us, we tried the coffee, masala chai, pancakes, and naan—all were solid and hit the spot, though the view is definitely the highlight.

A cozy, atmospheric place to rest your feet, grab a bite, and enjoy one of Jaipur’s most iconic views.

Amber Fort, Jaipur: A Detailed Review

Overview:
Amber Fort (or Amer Fort), located 11 km from Jaipur, is one of Rajasthan's most iconic landmarks and a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Built in 1592 by Raja Man Singh I and later expanded by successive rulers, the fort combines Mughal and Rajput architecture. Perched on a hill, it offers breathtaking views of Maota Lake and the surrounding landscape.

---

Key Highlights

1. Architectural Grandeur:

Constructed with red sandstone and marble, the fort features a blend of imposing strength and intricate artistry.

Sheesh Mahal (Mirror Palace): The most famous section, adorned with beautiful mirrors and intricate carvings that sparkle under light.

Diwan-i-Aam & Diwan-i-Khas: Public and private audience halls showcasing splendid frescoes and delicate designs.

Ganesh Pol: A gateway with exquisite frescoes, leading to the private quarters of the Maharaja.

2. Historical Significance:

Amber Fort served as the royal residence and a defense structure.

Rich in legends, it reflects the opulence of Rajput rulers and their strategic ingenuity.

3. Light and Sound Show:

An evening attraction that narrates the fort’s history through dramatic storytelling, sound effects, and lighting.

4. Maota Lake:

The picturesque lake at the base of the fort enhances its beauty and offers opportunities for stunning photographs.

5. Cultural Activities:

Elephant rides to the fort's entrance (optional but controversial due to ethical concerns).

Traditional puppet shows and local artisans near the fort.

---

Visitor Experience

Positives:

Historical Immersion: A perfect destination for history and architecture enthusiasts.

Scenic Beauty: Offers panoramic views of Jaipur and the surrounding hills.

Rich Cultural Vibes: Traditional performances and exhibitions add to the charm.

Negatives:

Crowded: Popular among tourists, it can get crowded, especially during weekends or festivals.

Accessibility: Reaching the top can be tiring; alternatives include jeeps or elephant rides.

Entry Fees: Slightly higher ticket costs, with additional charges for guides and certain areas.

---

Tips for Visitors

Best Time to Visit: Visit early morning or late afternoon to avoid the heat and crowds.

Duration: Allocate 2-3 hours to explore the fort thoroughly.

Guide or Audio Guide: Opt for a guide to learn about the fort's history and architecture in depth.

Ethical Concerns: Consider walking or taking a jeep instead of an elephant ride.

Evening Visit: Stay for the light and sound show for a unique experience.

---

Conclusion

Amber Fort is a jewel in Jaipur

reviews.reviewText:
Visiting Amber Fort was truly a memorable experience! I highly recommend going early in the morning – the temperature is pleasant, and the crowd is minimal, making it perfect to explore the fort peacefully and click great photos without much disturbance.

A small tip: do not book a jeep to reach the fort entrance. It’s completely unnecessary. The walk uphill is hardly 200-300 meters and very manageable, even in casual footwear.

Hiring a guide is a must if you want to understand the rich history and architectural details of the fort. The official guide charges are ₹400 for a group of 1-4 people and ₹600 for a group of 6-14. It’s definitely worth it for the added insight.

One important caution: avoid buying souvenirs from the shops inside the fort. They are extremely overpriced – you can find the same items outside the fort or in the local markets for 4-5 times cheaper.

Overall, Amber Fort is stunning and offers a great start to your Jaipur trip if you plan wisely!

I’d highly recommend taking a local guide........they share fascinating stories, little-known facts, and bring the fort’s past to life in a way that signboards never can. The architecture is stunning........with a perfect blend of Rajput charm and Mughal elegance, and the views of Maota Lake from the top are picture-perfect.
If you can........arrive early to enjoy the elephant ride up to the fort........it’s a unique, royal touch to the experience. For a different vibe........there’s also a light and sound show in the evening that tells the fort’s history beautifully.
Amber Fort isn’t just a sightseeing spot........it’s a walk through Rajasthan’s glorious past........and honestly........it’s one of Jaipur’s must-visits.

Amber Fort is a must-visit when in Jaipur — the architecture, history, and views are truly mesmerizing. It’s highly recommended to hire a government-certified guide (around ₹400), as they give you a real understanding of the fort’s history and also help with the best photo spots. Exploring the fort takes about 1–2 hours including photo sessions.

To avoid the rush, reach by 10–11 am — on weekends, parking queues can stretch up to an hour. If you’re in a cab with a guide, they’ll usually take you through the village shortcut and park at the top, saving you a lot of time. Walking through the fort makes you appreciate how such massive structures were built centuries ago without modern machinery. An unforgettable experience and one of the highlights of Jaipur! If you want to save time, skip the ticket queue by booking through the OBMS app — it’s quick and hassle-free.

placeMetadata.name: Jantar Mantar

sources.snippet: Located near the City Palace in the regal city of Jaipur, Jantar Mantar is the largest stone astronomical observatory in the world. Owing to its rich cultural, heritage and scientific value, Jantar Mantar in Jaipur has also been featured on UNESCO's list of World Heritage Sites. This ancient study boasts of nineteen instruments built out of stone and brass and was built by Raja Sawai Jai Singh in 1727-33.
sources.shortName: 52 Best Places to visit in Jaipur | Top Tourist Attractions

placeMetadata.description: 18th-century park & heritage site with fixed instruments for making astronomical observations.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Jantar Mantar in Jaipur is a fascinating 18th-century heritage site that stands as a testament to the astronomical prowess of its creator, Maharaj Sawai Jai Singh II. This remarkable observatory, constructed in 1726 from masonry, marble, and brass, features an array of fixed instruments known as yantras. These large-scale structures resemble abstract sculptures but serve a serious purpose: they accurately measure celestial phenomena such as timekeeping, star locations, planetary angles, and even predict eclipses.
placeMetadata.address: Malve Nagar, J.D.A. Market, Pink City, Jaipur, Rajasthan 302002, India

🛕 Khole Ke Hanuman Ji Temple, Jaipur – A Divine Retreat in the Aravallis
Khole Ke Hanuman Ji is one of the most revered and scenic temples in Jaipur, dedicated to Lord Hanuman. Nestled in the lush green Aravalli hills, the temple offers not only spiritual peace but also breathtaking panoramic views of Jaipur city.
________________________________________
📍 Location & Accessibility
•	Situated around 6–7 km from Jaipur city center (near Ghat Ki Guni tunnel on Delhi bypass).
•	Well-connected by road, autos, and taxis.
•	Vehicles can go almost up to the top; ample parking space is available.
•	A bit of walking or climbing stairs is required to reach the main sanctum if you're exploring on foot.
________________________________________
🌟 Temple Highlights
•	Presiding Deity: Lord Hanuman, worshipped in a powerful and unique form.
•	The idol is believed to be swayambhu (self-manifested), and the place holds deep mythological and spiritual significance.
•	The temple complex includes other shrines too (Ram, Sita, Shiv, etc.) and a goshala (cow shelter).
•	Beautiful Rajasthani architecture with red sandstone, arches, and traditional carvings.
•	The temple also organizes daily aarti and special events on Tuesdays and Saturdays, which are considered auspicious for Hanuman devotees.
________________________________________
🧘 Spiritual Experience
•	Peaceful and clean environment—perfect for meditation, prayer, or a calm retreat from city life.
•	Surrounded by hills and trees, you truly feel close to nature and the divine.
•	Devotees often report a powerful energy at the temple and a sense of inner calm after visiting.
________________________________________
🥗 Prasadam & Facilities
•	The temple is known for offering free prasad, especially during special days.
•	Food counters offer satvik meals at affordable rates.
•	There’s a clean seating/dining hall for pilgrims.
•	Drinking water and well-maintained washrooms are available.
•	The place is senior citizen and family-friendly with resting spots and shaded areas.
________________________________________
📸 Photography & Views
•	From the top, you get stunning views of Jaipur city and the surrounding hills.
•	The temple’s elevated location makes it a great spot for sunrise and sunset views.
•	Ideal for both spiritual seekers and casual tourists looking for peaceful scenery.
________________________________________
✅ Summary Tips
•	🕘 Best time to visit: Early morning or late evening for aarti and cooler weather.
•	👫 Who should visit: Devotees, families, tourists, spiritual seekers.
•	👟 Footwear: Remove shoes before entering the temple area.
•	📷 Carry your camera or phone for great landscape and temple shots.
________________________________________
⚠️ Areas to Improve
•	During festivals or Tuesdays, the temple can get very crowded—expect longer waiting time.
•	Signage could be improved for first-time visitors.
•	More shaded rest areas could help, especially in summer months.
________________________________________
💬 Final Verdict
Khole Ke Hanuman Ji is more than just a temple—it’s an experience of faith, nature, and peace. Whether you’re visiting for spiritual reasons or just to explore Jaipur’s hidden gems, this hilltop temple is a must-visit for its serenity, cleanliness, and panoramic beauty. It truly captures the spiritual heartbeat of Jaipur.

Very nice temple. Good arrangements by temple committee. Free parking available. If you have time, you can take rope way ride up to the hill top of ma Vaishno Devi temple. Two way ride costs 189 Rs per person. Hanuman mandir is most beautiful temple i have ever seen. People sit infront of Hanuman ji and recite Hanuman chalisa continuously. Superb vibes.

JAY SHREE RAM
"Khole Ke Hanuman Ji Temple is a must-visit destination in Jaipur! The temple is beautifully located on a hill, and the ropeway ride (₹189 both ways) offers breathtaking views of the city. Not only can you visit the revered Hanuman Mandir, but you can also pay your respects at the Mata Vaishno Devi temple situated atop the hill. The scenic views of Jaipur from the top are simply stunning. You can choose to hike up for a more adventurous experience or take the convenient ropeway. A perfect blend of spirituality and adventure!"

A truly peaceful and spiritual place nestled in the Aravalli hills. Visiting Khole Ke Hanumanji offers not just divine blessings but also a beautiful escape from the city’s hustle. The atmosphere is calm. Don’t miss walking a little further uphill to the Vaishno Devi Mandir. It's a perfect spot for those who enjoy devotion and nature both.
Another special thing here is that many devotees organise Dal Baati Churma bhandaras. If you're lucky, you might get to enjoy a delicious Rajasthani meal after your darshan.

A Holy place of Lord Hanuman, which is situated in Jaipur City, it's surrounded by beautiful mountains and Forest, in rainy season, the surrounding area looks so Beautiful, Temple having Lord Rama & 12 Jyotorlinga Temple also at upstairs..
Always recommended everyone to visit once here..

Khole Ke Hanuman Ji Temple, Jaipur

Nestled amidst the serene Aravalli hills, Khole Ke Hanuman Ji Temple stands as a peaceful and spiritually uplifting destination in Jaipur. The temple, dedicated to Lord Hanuman, is known not only for its divine aura but also for its unique location which offers panoramic views of the surrounding hills and cityscape.

Approaching the temple itself feels like an experience; the winding road through green hills adds to the charm. Once you reach, the first thing that strikes you is the grand entrance and the impressive architecture. The temple has been beautifully developed over the years, with intricate carvings and spacious courtyards that reflect traditional Rajasthani style. The massive Hanuman idol here exudes a powerful presence, and devotees often speak of a deep sense of peace after darshan.

A major highlight is the cleanliness and systematic management of the premises, despite being a popular religious spot. There are designated areas for sitting and meditating, and the sound of devotional hymns playing
This is the most beautiful temple of Jaipur. You will not find this beautiful temple anywhere else in Jaipur. This temple is near the mountain.

sources.snippet: The Hanuman Temple, Hanuman Mandir, or Kole Ke Hanuman Ji is a temple dedicated to the Hindu monkey deity Hanuman. It’s commonly known to Westerners as the “monkey temple” but was told by a local that was disrespectful. There are actually two sides to this temple.

placeMetadata.description: Unique, historic Hindu site, known as "Monkey Temple," in a secluded setting with scenic views.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled in a serene and picturesque setting, Hanuman Temple, also known as Monkey Temple or Kole Ke Hanuman Ji, is a historic Hindu site dedicated to the revered monkey deity Hanuman. The temple offers stunning views and boasts remarkable architecture set amidst the mountains. Visitors can immerse themselves in the tranquil atmosphere while observing people singing, playing music, and even swimming in the holy water. The temple is home to Macaque monkeys that visitors can feed and observe.
placeMetadata.address: Galta Ji, Jaipur, Rajasthan 302031, India

reviews.reviewText: Super amazing place, we were lucky enough to see on festival

The temple is a gorgeously located near a hilly area and hence there is no access to the main shrine. You will find monkeys lingering around in enormous numbers. A wonderful experience is ensured. It seems difficult to get a cab here. Hence it is recommended to take necessary precautions. The premises were not very clean during my visit.

The place is very beautiful and quiet. The old buildings are renovated but still there is a scope for cleanliness. The water in the pond is clear but the around area is not that cleaned. Children take bath in it and people wash their clothes.
The temple uphill is the oldest temple of Lord Hanuman. Many people come to this temple often. And there are other temples also.
There is some trekking area also uphill side.

Amazing geography and architecture, the temple is set in between the mountains. Vibe is immaculate - people singing and playing music and swimming in the holy water.
Great place to see and feed monkeys (they're Macaques). Paid entry and you can get a guide. It was also very cool here as the breeze flows between the mountains.
Note that the monkeys are given so many bananas that they sometimes won't eat them. Our guide used salty chips, which the monkeys loved.

Unfortunately would not recommend. While it was lovely to see all of the monkeys roaming around, for a popular tourist attraction the temple was not well looked after and there was trash everywhere, arguably the most littered temple I’ve been to so far in India. Quite sad to see all of the monkeys and other animals eating the rubbish that was in the river, which ruined the entire experience. The people that work here are only there to get your money, they commented that the rubbish situation was awful but had no incentive to clear up. There were no bins anywhere either, which would have significantly helped. There is an additional charge to take pictures, which costs more than the entrance ticket and is an outright scam!. Hope someone with authority sees this comment and decides to take action. Very disappointing.
Disgusting mess. Absolute disgrace and rip off to charge tourists to see the filthy litter everywhere. Couldn't bare to stay longer than 5 minutes before leaving. Be better, management.

This was one of my favorite sights in Jaipur!
We came early in the morning at sunrise and it was a magical experience. We were the only tourists and it was a magnificent sight. The sunrise was beautiful and the swarm of monkeys that suddenly came was cool. The monkeys were adorable and very playful. I can recommend this place to anyone that want a great experience!
The cost is 50 INR for each camera you bring. Same price for foreigners as for locals.
Word of warning: The locals will try to get you into their shrines there is scattered around and then pressure you for money.

The temple is crowded of people and monkeys. And the monkeys are a little bit friendly and it's better to bring something with you for them and have fun with monkeys. But, the temple isn't Clean and it's a noisy place. And there is no connection there so it's better to go with your driver

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Jaipur Wax Museum at Nahargarh Fort is a unique attraction that showcases lifelike wax figures of famous personalities from around the world. Visitors can marvel at replicas of celebrities like Amitabh Bachchan, Deepika Padukone, and Jackie Chan, as well as historical icons such as Mahatma Gandhi and Albert Einstein. What sets this museum apart is its inclusion of Rajasthani kings, queens, and warriors alongside international figures.

reviews.reviewText: Nice place to visit in Jaipur tour. It's actually inside nahargarh fort. Ticket price is Rs 500. Can't click pictures inside the wax Museum by own mobile they provide a cameraman and charger Rs 25 for one picture.

Located within the majestic Nahargarh Fort, the Wax Museum is a unique attraction that brings together history, art, and entertainment. As I walked through the museum's halls, I was impressed by the lifelike wax sculptures of Indian and international icons.

_Pros:_

1. _Lifelike Wax Sculptures_: The museum's wax sculptures are incredibly realistic, with intricate details and expressions that seem to come alive.
2. _Diverse Range of Exhibits_: The museum features a wide range of exhibits, including Indian historical figures, international celebrities, and even mythological characters.
3. _Interactive and Engaging_: The museum offers an interactive experience, with visitors encouraged to take photos with the wax sculptures and participate in quizzes and games.
4. _Well-Maintained and Clean_: The museum is well-maintained and clean, with clear signage and helpful staff.

_Cons:_

1. _Limited Space_: The museum is relatively small, which can make it feel a bit cramped during peak hours.
2. _Some Exhibits May Seem Outdated_: A few of the exhibits, particularly those featuring international celebrities, may seem outdated or less relevant to contemporary audiences.

_Tips and Recommendations:_

- Plan your visit during off-peak hours to avoid crowds.
- Take plenty of photos with the wax sculptures – they make for great Instagram moments!
- Encourage kids to participate in the quizzes and games – it's a great way to make history and learning fun.
- Combine your visit with a tour of Nahargarh Fort for a comprehensive and memorable experience.

_Practical Information:_

- Address: Wax Museum Nahargarh, Nahargarh Fort, Jaipur-302001
Ticket price -500+

We also encountered a puppet show where we were tricked into watching and then pressured to pay, even though I politely declined. I don’t mind paying extra for a good experience, but I felt it was unfair to be forced into paying like that.

This place is situated in the area of Nahargarh Fort. This place have additional ticket charge of 500 per person in which you get to many things to cover including their Wax Museum of celebrities of Bollywood, Sports, Queen Victoria II, Jackie Chan. And another section of Wax statue were of kings of Nahargarh fort. The fit finish of the statues were top notch. You can even see the veins running through their hands.
The most mesmerizing thing was the Sheesh Mahal, which is a copy of original Sheesh Mahal which is situated in the Amer fort. Inside this replica you see all the Nakashies of mirrors made very delicately.
Sadly tacking pictures inside Sheesh mahal was  not allowed. Pictures were also chargeable for 200 for 8 photos which they will provide softcopy they'll click with their cameras .

One of the best places in Jaipur to visit - the Jaipur Wax Museum. I went there with my family on weekdays. You can reach there by auto or a cab.
You'll need to buy separate tickets for the Wax Museum, Royal Darbar and the Sheesh Mahal at the Nahargarh Fort. In my opinion, it's worth every single rupee.
One more thing, you are not allowed to take photographs inside either of these. But you can hire their DSLR guy for taking a bunch of photos. They charged ₹200 for 8 photos. Unfortunately, taking photos in Sheesh Mahal by any means is prohibited.
Have a look at these amazing wax statues.

I once visited there a few wax sculptures were good but few are not up to the mark, Sheeshmahal is one of their best presentation. It's about a 30-40 minutes tour. One star for Rs. 500 for entry ticket and really bad photography policy i.e. just 8 photos in soft copy for Rs. 200, second star for the guide included in ticket price.

The beautifully sculpted statues by Susanta Ray are displayed in the ‘Hall of Icons’ and ‘Royal Darbar’ sections of the fort. Each wax statue in Jaipur Wax Museum has been given a background that compliments the history of that legend.

Jaipur wax museum timings: Monday – Sunday 10am to 6pm
Jaipur Wax Museum entry fees: Indian tourists: INR 500/per person (the wax museum + Sheesh Mahal) | Foreign tourists: INR 700/per person for Wax Museum and Sheesh Mahal
Visiting duration: 1 hour

ops.insert: Palace built in the form of a high wall to screen royal ladies as they watched street festivities.
Opulent 18th-century palace of Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh II, now a museum & royal residence.
Historic stepwell & rainwater catchment known for its picturesque symmetrical stairways.
In the middle of Man Sagar Lake sits this grand palace made of red sandstone, most of it submerged.
Elaborate fort built in 1734 in the hills above Jaipur, offering sweeping views of the city.
Elegant museum built in 1887 showcasing Indian art, arms, jewels, furniture, artefacts & more.
Built to protect the Amber Fort complex below, this 3-km-long fort offers a museum & views.
Majestic, intricately carved stone monuments are the highlight at this royal crematory.
The city palace is on view from this chill rooftop cafe for light meals, snacks & drinks.
The Jal Mahal palace sits in this lake created in 1610, a scenic destination for bird watching.
This archaeological site features traditional funeral monuments honoring royal women of the past.
Ornately decorated art deco/modern movie theatre owned by a jewellery dynasty.

Jaipur is the capital of India’s Rajasthan state. It evokes the royal family that once ruled the region and that, in 1727, founded what is now called the Old City, or “Pink City” for its trademark building color. At the center of its stately street grid (notable in India) stands the opulent, colonnaded City Palace complex. With gardens, courtyards and museums, part of it is still a royal residence.
Structure known as both Amer and Amber, with Hindu & Muslim elements & offering elephant rides.
18th-century park & heritage site with fixed instruments for making astronomical observations.
Unique, historic Hindu site, known as "Monkey Temple," in a secluded setting with scenic views.
